THE SECOND part of the Myrror of Knighthood.

CONTAINING TWO Several Books, wherein is entreated the valiant deeds of
Arms of sundry worthy Knights, very delightful to be read, and nothing
hurtful to be regarded.

NOW NEWLY TRANSLAted out of Spanish into our vulgar tongue by R.P.

IMPRINTED AT London by Thomas Este. 1583.

TO THE RIGHT Worshipful, and my very good friend, Master Edward Cordele,
Esquire.
ARISTOTLE (right Worshipful) being demanded, what benefit he had obtained
by Philosophy, answered: This is my gain, that uncommanded I can do that I
ought, and avoid doing that I should not; For, (says he) the ignorant for
fear of punishment abstain from evil, but the sapient can shun the same of
their own accord: noting, that studious exercise brings experience, and
makes as well civil policy, as martial prowess apparent. For which cause,
there have been sundry in times past, and some in this our present age, that
have not only penned with great labor the laudable works of Antiquity: but
also with as much travail have imitated certain old writers, by inuenting of
histories, no less profitable to repulse other hurtful pastimes, then
pleasant to pass away the tediousnes of time. Amongst the number of which
late works, there chanced about a three years since to come into my hands,
the first part of a Spanish translation, entitled, The Mirror of Knighthood:
which being published was so accepted, that I was importuned by sundry
Gentlemen (my very friends) to procure the translation of the second part:
whereto, (partly to accomplish their desires, and partly for the vulgar delight
of all) I condiscended.

And finding this Spaniard adorned with all good exercises, which pertained to
the exalting of virtue, and the extinguishing of vice: I labored (as much as
in me lay) to find an English Patron of conformable quality, whose
countenance might as well prefer him with the courteous, (...) protect him
among the envious. But I had not long bethought me, when the consideration of
your worships courtesy with the good report of your virtue, expelled that
doubt, and encouraged me to present you with this work. Beseeching you to
accept in good part, this poor present at the hands of him, which wishes to
you long life, with the continual increase of virtue, prosperity, and health:
and after this life endless felicity.

Your Worships most assured: T. E.

To the Reader.
GEntle Reader, I have here published the second part of the Myrrour of
Knighthoode, to the end that I might both satisfy thy desire, and yield unto
thee the delight, that by reading thereof thou may receive. About the verity
of the history I will not contend, neither would I wish thee to be more
curious to inquire, then thou would be desirous to ^ift the truth of each
transmutation in the Metamorphosis of Ovid, or ^uerie tale in the works of
Aesope: but to consider, that as the one by the transformation of reasonable
creatures into sundry brutishe shapes, shadowed the deformity of their wicked
lives: and the other by the manner of his beasts figured the beh^uiour of all
the estates of men, wishing a reformation of the ^uill, and a confirmation of
the good: So our Author has pleasantly compiled this present work, as well to
animate these that are by nature forward unto the exercise of arms, for to
exalt their fame: as also to provoke them that have hitherto slept in the bed
of security, to shun their wonted sloth, with desire rather honorably to
loose their lives in the defense of equity, then shamefully to live with
perpetual infamy. And whereas there are some so stoycall to contemn the
reading of historyes, alleging that their vain delight withdraw many from
other virtuous studies. I answer, that in any matter where vice is
reprehended, virtue is no way hindered, and although I must needs confess,
that the learned works of the liberal sciences are principallye to be
preferred, so it cannot be denied but that the pleasant style of a well penned
history, is as it were a whe^stone to the mind, being almost dulled with
continual study: and albeit there shall (peradventure) want the like grace of
eloquence in the translation as is requisite, yet I doubt not but the variety
of the matter shall make a sufficient recompense. Moreover (courteous Reader) I
request thee to note, that whereas the beginning of this part follows not
consequently upon the same book which was published in the name of the first
part, it is not to be imputed to any error committed in the translation of
this second part: for that it is verily the self same, that bears the title
of the second part in the Spanish tongue, but the book that lacks, is the
second book of the first part, which with as much speed as may be, shall be
joined thereunto. In the mean time, accept this in good part, which I now
present: wherein thou shall find the strange and wonderful prowess of the
worthy Trebatio, and his sons, nephews, kinsmen, and sundry other courageous
knights, mixed with many lamentable and sorrowful histories, together with the
redress of the wronged innocents. And so I end, committing this my labor, to
thy courteous consideration, and thy self to the Almighties tuition.

Thine: T.E.

THE FIRST BOOK of the second part of the Mirror of Knighthood: wherein is
entreated the valiant deeds of arms of many worthy Knights.
THE CRVELL Battle which past between the Knight of the Sun and the fierce
Giant Bramaraunt, in which bickering the Giant perceiving he must needs have
the worst, murdered himself. CAP. I.
WHEN THE GLITTERING armor of Aeneas of Troie was at the request of his Mother
Venus forged in Vulcan his shop, the well s^eeled hamme^s did not temper and
beat it with grea^er (...), ^hen the heroical son of Trebatio ((...) the
stou^ Pagan Bramarant through the midst of the Grecian woods,) did with his
(...) blows upon his armor, mangling by little and (...) his strong and
lusty body, so much the more their choler increased, as the combat did endure
between them. There were present at this bickering the renoumed* Emperor
Trebatio, Alicandro the king of Hungary and his Grandfather, with many other
puissaunt Princes and great Lords, who with no small admiration did behold
^he exceeding fierceness with which they let drive their blows, the one at
the other, which did resound an Eckoe in the air, and yielded a terrible noise
in the woods. This battle did continue between the^ ye space of two long
hours, and albeit it was fierce and sharp, the valor of the incensed knight
of the Sun prevailed not to abate or exstinguish the rage of the Pagan, and
much less could the force of the Tartarian quail in any sort the courage of
the princely Grecian. The skirmish being hot, and the redoubted son of Trebatio
perceiving that it endured very long without certainty who had the better:
heerevpon being greatly inflamed with fury, lifted up his peisant club above
his head, and did discharge it upon the pagan his left shoulder, in such sort,
(that notwithstanding his strength) he was forced to shrink backward, and so
fell flat upon his right side, being greatly dismayed at ye blow, and much
more at the fall: he began to recover himself at length by the friendly help
of an ash tree which was close by him, for otherwise his unwieldy body had
taken more pause upon the ground. Scantly had be taken good footing when he
perceived the knight of the Sun sort him another sequence aunswerable to ye
first. The Giant being unprovided of any trumpe to cast in his way, whereupon
he was driven to close with the Grecian, and having ceazed his body with his
sharp talents, he began to gripe him very hard: The heroical Prince seeing
himself thus embraced contrary to the custom of all courtesy, began to
shift, for to avoid this course entertainment so well as he might, but wanting
more time then courage he was thereby tript to the ground. And finding
himself laden with his enemy he was thereby compelled to forsake his club, and
by all means to seek to shake off that unfriendly burden. Therefore catching
Bramarant by the middle with no less agilitie then fury, he did violentlye
pull him underneath: whereby he requited him in part, for the discourtesie of
the former fall. There did they both show their inestimable forces, and passing
nimblenesse of body, in this cruel and dangerous encountering. And thus they
long time tumbled and tossed each other on the grass, some times not moving
for want of breath, otherwhiles wallowing together to get the masterie,
yielding forth most terrible groninges, by reason of the great pains and
weariness that they sustained in this hard conflict, at length they set each
other at liberty, and then start upon their feet, and began to fight as
fiercely as before. The Knight of the Sun drawing out his Sword, supposed
that no resistaunce of the enemy, how strong so ever it were, could suspend
the execution of his purpose, the Moore likewise took hold of his heavy
trenchaunt blade, cursing and banning his Gods, that they had endued this
Knight with so great force and prowess. Being in this brainsicke mood, he
would not attempt to make experience of his enemies force again, but
flourishing his sword amongst the troop, caused the^ to sunder themselves and
so in flying, made a broad lane between them, and ran to shrowde himself
into the thickest of the Wood, that he could, leaving the people in a great
admiration: The noble knight of the Sun when he beheld that his champion
betook him to his heels in so great have, whether he did it for fear (which
was unlikely being a stout champio^) or for devilish madness, (which might seem
true) being no christian, called for his horse, and could not be persuaded
from pursuing ye Pagan, by the Emperor his father, making a semblaunce of
great anger by his countenance, his horse being brought by one of his
esquires, he mounted into the Saddle very lightly, without help of his
stiroppes, and broching his courser with the Spurs, he made him run so
swifte, that he seemed another Perseus upon his Pegasus, to them that beheld
him. He ceased not to course up and down the Forest, with set purpose to
single out his Enemy, and not to rest until he had subdued him, or else to
be conquered by the virtue of his adversaries force.

Noble Rosicleer perceiving his brother to be inclyned for to take revenge of
the Pagan, and thereby mistrusting least that some froward mischaunce might
attend upon him (which fickle fortune does usually afford), heerevppon did
call for his horse and armor out of hand, which being brought with as much
speed as might be, in so short a time he being furnished with his own weapons
and armor, he leapt up nimbly into ye saddle, and posted through the forest
in as great have as he might, following his brother in the same path whether he
went, where we will leave him, to make rehearsal of that which did befall in the
Emperors court, in the mean time: when as ye beholders had somewhat staide
themselves in remembering this notable battle, and had as it were forgotten
the sharp brunts ye two champions sustained, the Emperor with ye rest were
somewhat recomforted to see how lovingly Rosicleer did follow to aid and succor
his brother, and discoursing by the way of the battle, and of the incredible
strength and courage of the Pagan, they withdrew themselves into their tents:
being not long there, news was spread abroad in the court of the loss of
Clarim^nt, which report when the Empres hard, it laid such an impression of
grief in her Imperial heart, that albeit she was an Empress and had ruledome
of many nations, yet had she not so much power over her self, but presently
thereupon she fell into an extreme Ecstasy between the Empress Claridianas
arms. The Queens and Ladies beholding so tragical and sudden mischaunce,
they clustered altogether, and with certain drugs which they had about them in
a readiness, they somewhat revived her again, she being before greatly
distraughted out of her wits and senses. And with sorrowing sighs replenished
with much martyrdom, descending from the bottom of her heart, bathing also
her beautiful visage with two streams of salt tears gushing from her eyes,
with a lamentable voice she delivered certain speeches, which did move the
assistaunts unto very great compassion: To whom the emperor came (although he
was God wot, in such plight himself, that his case rather required more
comfort) then to visit the comfortless: yet notwithstandding he with a grave
countenance, very lovingly did cherish and persuade her: which speeches of his
sauoured somewhat of an angry show of reprehension, in the end he wrought so
much with her, as she was fully recovered and contented. The Emperor not to
seem daunted with any thing, but to make a more apparaunt show of his valor,
he commanded his huntsmen to continue the sport, and in outward semblance
seemed to be so merry as ever he was, whereas in truth he was secretly wringed,
for the exceeding great passion which he saw the lady Claridiana endure, for
the sodeine absence of him who was newly married unto her, and had begotten her
with child. After three days were passed, they were desirous to return to
the City again, and taking up their tents, they laid all things in order,
and in readiness to proceed on their journey. But as they began to martch on
their way, they might perceive coming a long by the Forest side a Coach, all
covered over with black Searge, which four horses did draw, trapped with
such like black furniture. Before it eight knights came riding, with
Targettes and armor, all out of order, and broken, which did very well
express, that they escaped from some dangerous and hot skirmish. Behind the
Coche did attend as many more knights, having their armor suitable to the
first, all did bear black devices, the barbature of their Horses, aunswerable
to the same. The Emperor and Knights which beheld this same show, being all
black in mourning wise, did rain their horses to know what came in the same
Coach.

Here must I digress and recite unto you the cruel order and miserable end
of the unfortunate Pagan, and will return at length to relate unto you, what
did betide the Emperor and his company, after this sight of the Coche. The
devilish More Bramaraunt ran through the Grecian forests (a hellish fury
being his guide) yelling and braieng against his Gods, and as a starued Tiger
he trauased the woods, cutting down oaks, and r^oting from ye ground pine
apple trees, as if they had been sle^der reeds. And being plunged in this
pansiue mood, he entered into ye highest degree of his melancholic passions,
debating with himself, why should it not be possible yt his mighty hand should
conquer and subdue one silly Knight. But other sometimes descending from ye
mood into a more mad and frantic kind of behavior, this disturbed Moore did
bend himself toward the midst of ye wood, and keeeping on his right hand, he
repaired toward the brink of a broad and deep river which ran by that wood,
where he purposed to ease his weary lims: and the better to perform his
desire, he unlaced his helmet, and hurlde it scornfully to the ground. Now the
infernal furies began to visit the Moore, and attended to sting his poisoned
breasts, in such sort, that what with desire of revenge, and sorrow for his
late mishap, he was all kindeled in fire, having tossed many thoughts in his
crabbed mind. In the end, he cast up his wretched eyes to the heavens, saying:
O ye treacherous Gods, ioyn in league to defend your selves from mine
unfortunate hand, stay not, but muster your forces together, for if mine own
hand in the mean while be no impeachment to the cause, by pulling out my
heart, I will change the color of these christalline waters with the
Sacrifices of your blood: for no doubt there rests more valor in this one
knigh^, then in you all, when you are together. O ye dastardly cowards, where
are ye now become? Trust ye to this, that I have in more regard the worthiness
of that knight that fought against me, then I have in lyking your famed forces.
And seeing yt neither your powers nor my strength, may not paragon to his
courage, and to the end, ye shall not flatter your selves with a good opinion of
your own sovereignty, being insufficient to succor me, and much less unable
to suppress my will, or bridle my desire, I will renounce you all, and trust no
more to your favors. After he had thus spoken, forthwith he began to pull in
sunder his strong and bright shining armor, and what with outragiousnes, or
with sorrow which did greatly gall him, he cast from him one piece here,
another there: and blaspheming against al his Gods, he said: What does it
avail me your virtue, your favors, or mine own strength? is it not
altogether weakness? is it not a show without substance? Have you not
suffered my father to be slain without taking revenge? have you not seen me
subdued, wanting forces to requite it? Might not my father have been preferred
before Jupiter for gravity and wit? before Alcides for prowess? and before
Mars for courage? Can I otherwise conceive, but that you are all dastards, in
yt you take no revenge: deaf, in yt you will not hear the complaints of the
oppressed: and blind in that you cannot see the deserts of me. I should think
truly my fathers forces exceeding you all, ye have been a mean to breed his
death so soon. Why did you not assist me against ye Emperor Trebatio? why did
you not maintain me against ye knight, yt has conquered (...) in ye field. O
ye faint har^ed wretches, what has brought me hither, thus in the prime of my
youth to be put to shame, by being subdued of this knight. I will use such
means, yt none of you shall take revenge of me, by dieng at my enemies hands:
neither shall any have occasion to triumph and say, yt he has slain the
knight Bramarant. And speaking these and like speeches, he took his sword into
his hand and said. O good and faithful sword, release me from ye shame which I
deserve, in that I have not executed yt, which I did covenant to atchieue by
thee, since yt neither thy trencha^t edges, nor my approved stoutnes have
sufficiently played their parts, to satisfy that, whereunto my promise has
bound me. A cowardly arm did hold thee, a dastardly heart did direct thee, and
an evil guerdon be thy glory. Well, I will shroud thee in such sort, yt
hereafter thou shall not stand any other hardy knight in steed, nor be
subject to any man as thou have been to me. This only thing I request of
thee, if any of ye Gods carry ye good will to take the up to serve their own
needs, expres in what small regard my vnco^quered heart held the^, and thou shall
perceive, that they are not so valiant and stout as I am, or ever have been.
Having thus said, he cast it in the deepest part of the river, not having any
more weapons but a poor poynado, which usually he did wear about him: and
taking it in his hand, delivered these speeches unto it. Thou silly bodkin
shall finish ye piece of work, which all Christendom was never able at any
time to begin, I mean in bereauing me of my weary and lingering life, for I
above all men only deserve to leese it, seeing that I being the son of so
valiant a Father, have not showed any spark of that valor which by right
ought to descend to me from mine auncestour, since then I have digressed, I
repute my self unworthy to be registered for his son. O how worthily do
thou deserve death unfortunate Bramarant, since there are so few buddes of
valor springing in thee. And let me not deny but that mine ancestors
deserved to find much more favor at the Gods hands then I have done.
Forasmuch therefore as my cas^ is so bad, I will neither commend my soul to
the tuition of the Gods, neither will I crave of any man so small a favor as a
grave for my wretched body. Yielding forth these reasons with a great and
pitiful sigh, descending from his heavy heart, he stabde the Dagger amiddest
his ribs, which pierced unto the liver and heart, and so the vital powers
striving with death, and his miserable carcass beating up and down the small
sands for life, there dyed in this sort the most valiant and stout Pagan,
whose semblable the world did never yet bring forth, most unworthy (God
knows) of so cruel and pitiful an end.

The worthy Knight Rosicleer finding Bramaraunt giving up the ghost, after he
was dead, did entombe his corpse near unto a Pineapple tree, wherein he did
ingraue an Epitaph. Cap. 2.
THE last pang and deadly gasp that the valiant Tartarian yielded, being
distressed between life and death, was ouerheard by noble Rosicleer, who by
chance (pursuing him and his brother) repaired to that place where the Moore
lay wallowing: and aiming very well by his sorrowful sighs, that he endured
heaps of passions, rained his horse toward that way where he heard so shrill
these gronings, and staieng a while to hear his pitiful complaints, laid
himself squat upon ye ground, not far from whence ye dead pagan lay imbrued in
his blood. And wondering how so deep a river might change his color by the
loss of the blood of one man, began to toss^ the dead corpse up and down,
presuming in himself, that rather the passion of the mind or the weight of
his armor then any deadly blow that he had received, had brought him to this
extremity. In the end, seeing his visage so besmeared with blood, as he could
not truly guess what Knight he might be, insomuch as he never saw him but
in his Beauer. Heerevppon he wondered greatly, partlye to see that this Knight
was so strong timbered, but principally to see his stern and sour
countenance. And by as much as he could gather by his foresaid complaints, he
imagined him to be the executioner of his own body. He pausing somewhat in a
mase, in viewing this lamentable slaughter of Bramarant, without moving his
eyes either one way or other, until in the end he looked up, being greatly
afflicted in his mind, and deeply sighing, cast his eyes that way where the
Moore his armor lay strawed as you have already heard, and seeing them to
be so great and strong, he went about for to piece and lay them all in order,
which thing being done, he knew by the device ingraued in them, that this was
Bramaraunt the More, which lay thus murdered. His stout heart could not
brook this sorrowful Sacrifice, but in considering of the miserable end
which did befall upon this Tartarian, he could not but shed from his eyes
some trickeling tears, saying: O wretched world, what booteth so much the
mighty limbs and exceeding forces of any man, when as thou with thy smooth
and flattering face, do draw them at last that follow thy course* to such a
wretched end, and at the pinch of all their pangs thou forsakest them. O
Bramarant, Bramarant, whose forces did resist the mighty Grecian army, the
incomperable strength of my brother, the tried knight of the Sun, and have
not had power to suppress thine own outrageous passions. Alas thy valor
and noble courage did require, nay rather deserve, more glory, and more
guerdon then this. Thy strong and fast knit members did merit to be entombed in
a more rich Sepulcher, then in this weat and small sands, and God knows,
never deserved to be a pluming stock to the ravenous Fowls of the air. What
did move thee, O most unhappy amongst all men, to make thy angry arm
bereave thee of thine own life? It could be nothing else I am sure, but thy
surpassing great pride: What did move thee to this untimely death, as it well
may be termed, since thy fortune has been such, I will not suffer thy body
to be pulled in fitters with hungry beasts and ravenous Harpies, neither
will I see thine armor dispearsed in such sort, without bestowing upon thee
the due desert of honor, which are sufficient witnesses of the sacrifice of
thine own body, and a testimony of that which thou did offer up to thy
Gods, by sprinkling the pleasant ^ieldes and green grass with such a crimsin
color. And after having thus pitifully bewailed the Moore, he took his
helmet, and pulling out the murdering dagger, which was nailed close to the
hiltes in his body, he dug a deep grave therewith, wherein was inter^ed the
miserable body of the unfortunate Tartarian. Likewise he did hang the armor
upon a very fair and high Pine apple tree, which was near unto his grave,
and with the point of his Daggar did ingraue this Epitaph in the rind of the
Tree.

This Pine with stretched arms oreshades a valiant knight,
Whose body here interred lie^, and Bramarant he hight:
In strength and feats of arms, he most men did surpass,
A Pagan borne, his native soil and land Tartaria was.
His own right hand, a woeful case, himself did slay,
And re^t his heart which never was subdude before that day
Trebatios son first there this mighty More has found,
Twixt life and death, and with his hands ingrau'de him in this ground.
A Monument too base unfitting his degree,
Whose blood and acts in tomb of gold interd deserud to be*
In this fair growing pine for honor of his name,
He did ingraue these lines, to be a record of his fame.
And placed his armor here, forbidding any Knight,
To take it hence, unless he be as stout as he in fight.
And who so shall it wear, must wars continue still,
With Grecian Lords, as Bramarant did, this stands for my will.
Now having finished this piece of work, he said: Pardon me valiant Moore,
I beseech thee, because at this time and in this place I do not attribute so
much honor to thee as thou deseruest: yet I do promise thee by the faith of a
Christian knight, to fulfill every point in this Epitaph, (I esteem so much)
though it be done with the loss of my life. And to make the more assurance
of this my promise, I vow that no year shall pass, but tha^ I will come to
visit thy Sepulcher, to see and know who has been so hardy and ventrous,
as to think himself worthy to carry away thy heroycall armor.

And in speaking these and such other like words, he did not forget to mingle
them with some trickling tears, his courageous heart was so tormented in
meditating of the lamentable end of this desperate More. Having finished his
talk and travail, without longer abode, he mounted upon his cours^r, and
directed himself thorough the thickest of the Wood, determining always to
accomplish yt which he promised, although it did import so much in it, as the
weight of his life, as you shall perceive hereafter. This valiant knight
continued not without great grief of mind, in remembering the order of ye
death of Bramarant, which did continually occupy his memory. And as he went
thus drowned in sudde^ of sorrow, he knew not, neither cared he which way his
horse did carry him, until the darkness of the night surprised him, so that
he could not pass any further, wherefore he was constrained to light from
his horse to walk on foot, and to remain in that place all Night, wherefore
he unbridled his horse, and gave him liberty to feed on the sweet grass,
(whereof he had great need) having endured much travel before. He likewise
unlaced his helmet, and laying it under his head in steed of a pillow (being a
course bolster for an Emperors son) rested his werie lims upon ye green
medowe. And thus being alone and solitary, he could not suspend the
remembrance of those passions, which the day before he had passed. Also those
conceits did call to account more sorrows, and made him to be grieved for his
long absence from his best beloved Oliuia, whose beautye he entertained so
deeply in his mind, as neither time, place, nor any fortune whatsoever, could
separate her from his good opinion. Nourishing his mind with this sweet
passion, he continually tossed too and fro: and in the end, seeing the bright
shining Moon, and fixing his eyes upon it, he began to contemplate the divine
power of almighty God, not wondering also a little, how that ye heavens were
beautified with golden stars, and how the great Architector of the world, had
settled every one in his due and con^enient place, which ingendered a great
confusion in his mind. These cogitations summoned him to sleep, wherein he
had not taken long rest, but yt he heard on his le^^^ hand a harmonious sound
of some musical instrument, and therewith all so pleasant and Angelical a voice
answerable to the same, yt he supposed it to descend from ye heavens. The
prince start up, and softly went through the dark thicket^es, to the end he
might approach the more nearer, thereby to be pertaker of that celestial
music, but he was hindered of his journey, for that Dianas brightness was
eclipsed with a Cloud: wherefore then lifting up his eyes, he might discrie
under a broad Pine apple tree, a certain Lady sitting upon a quishion of
black velvet, embrodered with diverse pretty knots of gold, whom he supposed
to be that Lady, with which her divine harmony delighted his troubled
spirits, her fair and yeolow hair untied, and hanging down beneath her
ears, did rest upon her comely shoulders, in such seemly sort, and so long,
that some part thereof touched the black velvet cloth, which did seem with
their golden color to represent some golden emblem, wouen in the same cloth.
She had before her Christalline breast, a goodly Lute, whereon she played (as
you have heard) this sweet music. There waited upon her person nine fair
damosells, arraied all alike, with gowns of black velvet, and on her one side
there lay prostrate a lusty and strong knight well proportioned in body, and
tall, harnessed in a black Diamond armor, without any other device, who was
very attentive to the music, which the fair Lady did sing: the tenor of
the which is comprised in these vearses following.

Strain forth a voice conformed to my heart,
and let my fingers heavy stops apply:
Whilst that my tongue in words bewray such smart,
as who them hears, may know in life I die.
Fowls, beasts and worms, that neighbor near this place,
All in your kinds, assist my woeful case.
Yea even the fish that in this river dwell,
whose clear sweet streams my tears have bitter made,
Will stay to hear the process which I tell,
the Nymphs also that haunt this grouie shade:
And Ecko eke, full glad of such a mate,
Will in my words bemone her passed state.
I love (aye me) whereby my joys I lost,
and am not loved, wherein fresh grief I find:
Proud Tyrant thou, with shame thy conquest bost,
thy faith, my fame, staind by thy cruel mind,
Who gotst with guile the guard of my good name,
And leau'st me now to ransacke of defame.
Cannot my face where nature prints her prays,
thy liking draw her A.b.c. there to know,
My hairs excel bright Phoebus golden rays,
my eyes more clear then stars in frost that show.
My cheeks likewise, for perfect white and red,
resemble blood that in the snow is shed.
The rest vnnamde does match all these likewise,
but lo my faith my form too far does pass,
Yea, form and faith he shunnes and does despise,
whom ceaseless I pursue from place to place:
Whereby though often my tender lims I tire,
My will yet fresh, through hope and sweet desire.
She made an end of her song with a pitiful sigh, and letting her lute fall
out of her hand, with a trembling voice she said. O Prince Zoylus, if thou
did or would know the great travail that this careful Damoisell
susteyneth for thy only cause, I do verily think, that albeit thou had
tasted of the water of the enchanted well of Merlin, yet could it never work
such effect in thee, as to make thee careless of my torments, since they are so
sharp, and I have sustained them so long.

These words were no sooner uttered by this sorrowful lady, but presently, the
knight start up, who was laid down close by the Lady, and could not be quiet,
until he had answered her thus. What breath has love made in your breast,
most delicate damsel? how has he subdued you with his blind force, unless
the great disdain and coffeehouse that the Tartarian Prince showed you do
oppress you, I know not why you should complain: why should not you quite his
discurtesie with like disgrace? why should you not make him taste of ye sower
which seems so bitter to you? You sent for me (you know) to come into Greece,
only to be revenged of his cruelty: and how often have you wished his head as
a Sacrifice in respect of his contempt? And how comes it now to pass, yt in
your songs he is remembered with such affection, thought upon with such
plain^s, and called upon as a divine creature? Believe me and doubt not of it
(good madame) if Fortune be so favorable to assist me in my purpose, I will
in such wise contriue these matters, that you shall never have any occasion to
lament his life, neither yet to suspect that he does bestow his good will and
liking upon some other Lady.

The afflicted Dame notwithstanding all these his comfortable speeches, could
not strip her self of any part of these exceeding sorrows, which so deeply
did sting her, whereupon she answered him in this order saying.

Prince of Mesopotamia, I sail even now between two doubts, whereby I do
not only doubt, but am also persuaded my shipwreck is hard at hand. For if
I become so froward, as to envy him whom I wish to be my friend, or that I
have so cankered a mind as to seek to destroy him whom I love so well, what
might be said of me otherwise then of a fained lover, and cruel homicide:
again, if on the other side I pardon his death, whose life and disdain breeds
me this sorrow might argue too much pity without desert. Alas, what luck
had I, that love should intrude himself so forcibly into my poor heart, and
govern there as chief Lord, and could he not have battered the breast of
Zoylo, whose de^ence in resisting had been more strong then mine, but the
weakest must to the wall, and the least able must bear the heauiest burden.
How gladsome would that day be unto me, wherein I might see my Knight abandon
his strangeness, and extend more favor upon me: or else alas, how willing
would I be that my afflicted heart were drawn out of his place by his bloody
hand. The poor Lady being not able to speak any more, wrong her hands
and stayed her self against a Pine apple tree, which was behind her back, at
the view whereof the Mesopotamian knight in great sorrow laid himself down
again, upon the green grass. And the Grecian Prince wondering at this
strange adventure, returned very softly to that place where he left his horse
feeding, with intent and purpose to encounter that Knight, so soon as Titan
should appear to light the world with his beams, and for no other cause but
only to deliver his friend from that prepensed malice. And when as ye fiery
Phaeton began with his glancing beams to shine, the Grecian Prince put on his
armor, laced his helmet, mounted upon his horse, and with a soft pace made
toward the Prince of Mes^potamia, who was now prepared to undertake his
journey with his company. After they had travailed a while, the Prince did
epsy them passing through a fair champain or field, and was greatly abashed
at the exceeding beauty of the Lady, whom he viewed a long time, and love
having tickeled him for that she was so rare a Phoenix, he thought for her sake
he could subdue all the world: wherefore he turned his eyes toward that
place where the Knight was, and if before he wondered at the Ladies comely
graces, not much less was he now amassed at the strong body of this knight,
and at his huge and well fashioned weapons, whereby he reputed him to be some
worthy and noble champion. After he had shaked off this imagination, he said
unto him: Knight, take thy weapons and armor for thy defense, for I am
desirous to have some trial of thee, before that thou do prove thy valor
with the Tartarian Prince, thereby peradventure to quite him (if I can) from
the like battle which thou do intend to have with him, at the request of
this Lady, and therefore I mean to prevent that devilish purpose which thou
have promised to accomplish The Moore heereat began to swell, and very
scornfully and with a fearful countenance replied. What fury or devil of
hell has placed so foolish a thought in thy brains, to undertake that exploit,
which the best of the Gods never durst enterprise: and not able to speak any
more, his cholar and rage was so great, he laid both his hands upon his
sword, and therewithal let fly at the Grecian Prince such a blow, that he
made his head redouble in his breast plate, and upon the neck of the same, he
discharged another upon him, which made him yield backward. The Grecian Prince
wondering at his incomperable strength and nimblenesse, drew out that strange
and unknown sword, which the Queen Iulia did give him, and lifting it above
his head with one of his accustomed blows, he did smite it upon the pagan his
helmet, which made him bow down his head to his saddle Pomell, so that his
senses were almost benumbed with the force of it, but being recovered, he
began by little and little to smite and wound the noble Prince, yet his
dexterity in fighting could little prevail, for the Prince stood not still,
but did so b^stur himself, (and with as great fury as the other) that he did
scarre his enemy in diverse places, which he felt not without great pain,
although he made no semblaunce of the same, whereupon the battle being
before but kindled, was now on a hot flame, both of them burning in revenge,
and therefore continued a good while furious and fierce, slashing maine blows
between them, which sounded a terrible noise in the thickness of the wood, as
if many Smithes had been hammering upon their Ansieldes. But whosoever had
then beheld the appalled countenance of the Lady, he would no doubt have
taken her for no living creature, so much did this desperate and fierce combat
astonish her comelye face. And thinking upon the valiant enemy of her
Knight, who like a Bear that has lost her yonglinges a^sailed him evermore*
on the one side she wished in her heart the victory over him, and on the other
side fearing to see her self all alone, she desired greatly truce between
them, and that they might part friendly, and that which did most glad her
mind was, yt oftentimes she did imagine (and yet but doubting of ye matter) if
perhaps this should be the knight whom she did take so great pains to find
out, and that which did confirm her surmise, was, that she heard him at the
first name ye Tartarian prince. In such and other like thoughts and doubts, the
comfortless Lady passed away her time: In the mean while that the
courageous Knights were busy how they might dispatch the one the other. But ye
crabbed Moore with both his hands gave the stout Grecian such a blow upon his
helmet, yt he made his horse neck a pillow for his head, wherewithal he began
to thumpe and beat all his feeling, and in this senseless sort was Rosicleer
carried up and down the plain by his horse, ye Moore pursuing him to cut off
his head, but as God would have it, he awaked as it were out of a dream, and
furiously recovering his sword, he turned back again, and repayed the
Paganne with such a forcible blow upon his friendly helmet, that his
wonderful strength made the well tempered steel to yield, and therewithal it
made him fall backwardes upon his horses buttocke, casting out blood out of his
mouth, his horse carrieng him here and there amidst the pleasant fields more
then half dead, but Rosicleer would not follow him, but did attend whether
and about what he went, who tarried not long but yt he inioyed his former
senses and strength, (being once almost dispossessed of them) and abashed to
see the Prince to have surmounted him by lending him such a cruel blow, so
extremely did all the furies in hell conspire in his breasts, that now having
reared up his swoorde, which fell from him by force of that unreasonable blow,
he broched his horse with his spurs amain, and with incredible swiftness he
encountered with the Grecian Prince, and hit him so mortal a stroke upon one
of his shoulders, that it made his bones rattle within his skin, but he
failed not to leave the print of his swoorde in some part of the sinnowed
flesh, so that now the battle seemed to be but begun, such was the
fierceness of both these stout champions. And both of them employed their
forces in smiting of each other, and also their wits were not idle how the one
by some s^ight might sooner cut off his enemy, because it grieved them both
that the battle begun two long hours since, should endure any longer
without advantage of any part, wherefore both did their diligence to finish
it by some way or other. And all this while it was very hard to know
whether of them had the better over the other, being equivalent in prowess
and manhood. But the courageous and fierce Grecian being angry in his mind
to see one only Knight to keep him at the staffes end so long, replenished
with an infernal furye, he began a fresh to double and redouble his mighty
and peysaunt blows upon the Pagan, whereat he had good cause to wonder: and
perceiving that his strength did more and more increase with his courage, he
began to blaspheme against his Gods, yet notwithstanding like a firce Lion
he thought to tear in pieces the worthy Grecian, wherewithal he let slip
so devilish a blow upon his head, that with the loss of his understanding,
he did almost fall from his horse: The worthy Rosicleer quickelye again
recovered, and seeing himself to be in such a plight, he turned his horse
so nimblye, that he scarce left his treading in the ground, and now when he
saw himself iumpe with his enimye, gathering together his forces and standing
upright in his stiroppes, he weelded his sharp Swoorde between his strong
and mighty arms, and thundered so deadlye a blow upon the Moore his
head-peece, (who indeed was not provided for any defense) the force whereof
made a division from the scull even to the very shoulders, the wretched Pagan
falling down dead to ye ground, ye most part of his blood came gushing out of
his body. Unneth had he fallen from his horse when the trembling and troubled
Lady did also fall from her Palfraie, as one that should give up the Ghost,
whom when her Gentlewomen did epsy, lighted all of their Palfrayes, and with
streams of salt tears began to lament her woeful case, and to accurse her
froward fortune, every one striving about her, to try if they could by any
means restore her again to her memory. The Prince seeing her in this
extremity, did also forsake his horse and come toward the place, where this
miserable Lady lay like a stake, and causing one of her Gentlewomen to fetch
a little water from the river which was hard by, he besprinckeled her
beautified visage with it, and thereupon she came to her self again, and
opened the dimmed windows of her dark body, and when she beheld the Prince
so nigh her, with a profounde sigh and pitiful voice she said. O cruel
homicide of my faithful and valiant champion: thou thirsty bloudsucker of the
royal blood of Mesapotamia, dispatch now, dispatch I say, to execute thy
fury with thy imbrued Swoorde upon my sorrowful heart, and speaking these
words she fell again into an ecstasy as before, which Rosicleer marking, and
gessing at her inward pain by her extearne countenance, he turned himself to
one of her Damoysells, which as he thought among the rest of her train seemed
the chiefest, in knowing most her Ladies secrets, and said unto her:
Gentlewoman, I see (God knows, not without great sorrow be it spoken) ye
grief yt your Lady indureth in viewing my face, therefore I pray you tell her
from me, that I entreat her to go to the Emperors court of Greece, and there
present her personage to his majesty, and certify him of all these accidents,
and there to stay my coming, for I mean shortly to return thither, and then
I promise her, that there I will use such means yt she shall inioye to her
great contentment, that thing, the want whereof does so greatly grieve her, and
because my words may carry more credit with her, you shall tell her, that
one of the Emperor Trebatio his sons, the greatest friend that the Tartarian
Prince has, did inform you this much. And heerevpon not tarieng for any
replye, he mounted upon his horse, coursing through the forest. When he was
gone, the Gentlewomen helped their lady by certain drugges which they brought
forth for preventing such mishaps, and so recontinued her health again, and
afterward expressed to her all that which the knights imparted unto them, which
report comforted her not a little. The grief which the Lady and her
Gentlewomen did sustain, in seeing a strange Knight glaunce by them armed,
and to remain in the wood alone without succor or comfort of any, I would
here set down before your eyes: but I am enforced to return to the famous
Rosicleer, and at this present, I will not make recital to you, what Knight
that was, who parting from Rosicleer did appear again unto him at his going
out of the forest.

Prince Rosicleer travailing on his way, having alredie taken leave of the
Princesses Ladies, did chance upon a certain adventure, and of the success
he had therein. Cap. 3.
THE valiant Rosicleer being departed from the sorrowful princess, went as he
thought the nearest way through the forest to find his brother, with set
purpose to make him acquainted with that which you have already heard, and
afterward to return back to Constantinople. So it happened that fortune
guyded him into a broad and large way, which was his direct pathe to
Constantinople, and turning him to the foot way where he saw a great gate in
hope to learn some news of the knight of the Sun. He had not travailed
long, but he descryed a far off a rank of men all armed, and they drawing
more near unto him, he perceived that they were xx. Knights armed with black
armor, and their head-peeces and beueres of the same color, and in their
company came a Chariot, all covered with black Searge so close, that it was
impossible to see what was within it, ye light came in through two windows
which were placed at the side of the Chariotte. Four horses did draw it, all
clad in black cloth, and there did ride two fair dwarfes, as guyders of the
same, all apparailed in black. Behind the same there came likewise ten
Knights clothed in like sort, and by their countenance they wear all right
sorrowful, so that the troop of the Knights that came with the Chariot were
thirty in number. With this heavy countenance and great straungenes, they
passed by Rosicleer, without speaking any word unto him: whereupon the Prince
came to those that waited behind, and demanded of them in courteous wise,
what they were, which were enclosed in that ^orrowfull Wagg^n, but the Knights
were so heavy and sad, that they made him no answer, but passed on forward,
which bred a more earnest desire in Rosicleer to know who was within, since that
with such mild speech he had demanded, and could not be resolved to any
purpose. And heerevpon without taking any further advise in the matter, he
rushed among them that enuyroned the Chariot, only to see what was within it,
but ere he might come near it, he was lette^ by two of the Knights which said
unto him: Stay thee Knight, stay thee, for if thou longest to know who is
here, thou shalt be hindered from it by us, which stand here to no other
purpose. It is my desire (said Rosicleer) and willingly would I be satisfied of
my request without entering into the combat, and if ye would afford me so much
courtesy, as to tell me the cause of so great sorrow, I should be heartelye
glad. Thou may not understand it, answered one of the Knights, at this
time, therefore depart thou hence in peace, unless thou will make experience of
our forces, which do attend upon it. I know not (replied Rosicleer) how it
shall betide me, but truly whether you will or no, I am purposed to see what is
within it. After he had thus spoken, he laid his hand upon his sword, and
without tarriaunce for more speeches, he hit one of them so strongly, that he
killed him. His companion seeing this, let drive at the Prince with all his
force, but the fierce Grecian suited him a pasport suitable to his companions:
which thing drove their companions into a wonderful admiration, and heerevppon
forgetting all courtesy, they altogether enuyroned the Prince, and struck at
him on every side: but the valiant Grecian seeing himself in such a prease,
it was not long, but that he did vnharnesse some, and maimed other some, and
others he struck down dead, and cursed was he unto whom he lent a full
blow. In such sort the Prince skirmished with those Knights, that they
began to recoyle, fearing the death, considering that it was better to
disclose to him that which with such humanity he had demanded of them.
Heerevppon the knights with blushing countenance made toward the Knight, and
being so weary as they were, which turned to their own harm, they struck
freshlye at him again, whereupon the Prince did cut and mangle them at his
own will. He then perceiving the small resistaunce that they made, he came
unto the Chariot, and pulling up the coue^^ure, he saw that there was within
it, a dead body all imbaulmed, and on the head of it, there was the Crown of a
King, which head unto the breast was divided in sunder with some blow, and he
did repute him for such a one by his royal garments, which were all imbrued
in blood. There sat in a Chair covered with black Cipers, at the foot of
this dead king, a Gentlewoman of a middle age, leaning her cheek upon her
hand, and her eyes shut, she bedewed her face and breasts with innumerable
brinish tears, and near unto her there sat another Gentlewoman, who seemed
to be but ten years of age, all wrapped in black, which Gentlewoman was so
fair, that she appeared unto his view more divine then humane.

The renowned Grecian Prince with great admiration and no less pity, beheld
this sorrowful sight, and at length the distressed Gentlewoman, opened her
heavy eyes, and seeing the Knight, knew he was none of hirs. Thervppon with an
angry countenance she said unto him, Who are you sir Knight which have been
so bold as to come and see what is here without my commandment? where are
my Knights and keepers which have not depended you the passage, nor brideled
your exceeding boldness? The courteous Grecian who greatly bewailed the sight
which he saw, and the great dolor wherein the Gentlewoman was, he answered
her soberly. Madame, I am a Knight, whose help if it might stand you in steed,
though it were with hazard of my life, you should find it ready at your
commandment: and as concerning the guard which have attended upon you, they
have done what lay in their power to prevent me, but all could not prevail.
The Lady attentively heard the speeches of the Knight, and hearing the tidings
he delivered her of her Knights, she lift up the other side of the covering of
her Chariotte, she espied some of her Knights murdered, other some hurt, and
other some all to be trampled under the horse feet. After she had seen the
great overthrow of her Knights, with an angry countenance she turned her to
the Knight and said: The Gods send thee a perpetual plague, since that in such
sort thou have entreated the best Knights in all my Province, and since that our
misfortune has been so great that thou have had the power to vanquish my
keepers, I beseech the Gods, that thy forces hereafter may prove as weak, as
my troop is now poor and slender. Follow on thy way, and suffer me to go
mine, with that company which has escaped thy cruel hand, what would thou
farther learn then that which thou have already seen? Besides this, my
griefs cannot afford me so much time as to recount them, neither has thy
courtesy wrought in me such good will as to recite them. When she had thus
spoken, she opened one of her casements, and made sign to the dwarfes which
^idde, that they should whip the horses, which when they had done, they went
like the wind, leaving ye Prince more discontented then he was at the
beginning. And without more tarriance, he continued on his journey, greatly
blaming the courtesy of so evil mannered people: and he travailed a long
time without encountering any thing worthy the recital, until he came unto
the shore of the Sea, wherein he saw a great boat of very fair workmanship,
upon which he had great delight to look, yet he did not forsake his way, and
he had not continued long in riding, but that he heard a woman's voice as he
thought, call unto him: Knight of the Princess Oliuia, succor this captive
Gentlewoman. At the call hereof, the Knight turned his head, and gazing on
all sides, he could not see who called him in such have, and so following his
way, he heard again a new voice which said unto him: Knight of Cupide,
thou never deniedst to any thy help, and wherefore do thou not succor me.
The Prince greatly astonished, turned himself to see if he could perceive who
called him, which thing when he could not do, it bred a bitter passion in him.
Going forward in his journey more careful then he was, he heard the third
time a voice cryeng unto him. O son of Trebatio, courageous Rosicleer, what is
become of that pity which was wont to dwell within thy valiant heart, toward
the succouring of the oppressed Ladies, why do thou now begin to fail me.
When he heard himself called by his proper name, it did strike him into a
greater dumpe then he was in before, heerewith imagining that the voice came
forth of the ship which he saw at the shore side, he lighted from his horse,
and nimbly leapte into the Boat, and his horse as if he had understanding
followed him. They were no sooner in the Boat, but it began to cut the Seas
with such swiftness, as the wind which has long time been imprisoned in his
cave, and could not get forth at any chinke, and it blewe now in such sort, as
Juno by long intercession entreated Eolus, who untying the chains, commanded
the Winds with all their fury to transport the enamored Aeneas and his
Troyans army into the deapth of the seas. Rosicleer was greatly amazed to see
himself thus swiftlye conuayed, and saw not any in the Boat which so often
^ad cried to him for succors. Here we will leave speaking of Rosicleer, and
will return to declare unto you, the many worthy deeds that his brother did
accomplish, suffering him to ride in his boat, as already has been recited
unto you.

The great sorrow that the knight of the Sun received in thinking of his own
disloyalty, and that which happened unto him. Cap. 4.
THE Knight of the Sun with great fury and have, wandered through the
Forests of Greece, as it has been already declared unto you, kindling the
air with fire, with that burning cholar wherein he was wrapped, unhappy had he
been, which at that time durst have undertaken to have resisted his purpose,
for while he was in this mood, there had been no roeke so hard, but he
would have torn in pieces, nor no hill so steep, but he would have pulled
down. In this sort he went all the day not finding any print of that he
sought for. The dark night did overtake him in the thickest of the Forest,
whereby he was enforced to a light and ease his horse, who fed upon ye green
grass, and he leaned himself under a high Pine tree, the place being so
solitary, it was a mean to draw him in mind of many things which had
already happened unto him, and specially it renewed the fresh assaults of
that love which passed between him and the Princess Lyndabrides musing with
himself what should move him so unkindly to forget her, and in comparing the
beauty of the Princess Lyndabrides with his beloved wife, he found the
Empress did far exceed her, and heerevpon the knights good will began to
kindle, and was inwardlye glad of his own choice, but this affection was
soon extinguished, so firmly setteled was that good will be bare unto the
Barbarian Lady. The impression whereof was so deep, that he altogether
forgot the ancient love that he had borne unto his beloved Empress,
whereupon with sorrowing sighs he sounded forth his grief, and with brinish
tears he said. Is there in the world any knight so little attainted with
love as I am, or can there, be any one so ungrateful as I, since that I bestow
no care upon one, so furnished with beauty, and endued with so many excellent
virtues. Alas Lyndabrydes, right worthy do I acknowledge my self to be
chastised with love, since that without reason I have transgressed his bounds.
As there is nothing in me to merit your divine beauty, so am I altogether
unworthy (being a disloyal Knight) any so vnderserued courtesy, but I will
promise you to execute upon my self a more sharp revenge, then lay in you to
give me, since that I have forfaited that bond wherein I was bound unto you. Oh
miserable knight what say thou in thine own defense, how can thou excuse
thy folly? have thou blotted out of thy mind yt sovereign courtesy of thy
Lady? or have thou suspended the sweet memory of her divine beutie, being so
rare an Empres? Oh traitorous heart why have thou yielded to this folly? and why
do thou not now repent this passed falt, since that love which first
enthralled thy mind, does now without ceasing torment thy heart? Oh wretch
that I am, what condign punishment may I bestow upon my self. O sacred
Emperico, thou gave me free possession of all, without reserving any thing,
thou did surrender to me thine Empire, and thou did yield to me thy
liberty, and I careless of my faith, and neglecting thy courtesy, could not
intertaine a good opinion of thee alone in my heart, according to thy desert,
but have been prevented by the Tartarian lady, who has made a breach in my
affection. Forgive me I beseech thee: Oh sorrow, oh intolerable grief, no
less sharp then death to see my heart divided in twain. Is it possible yt I
can live and sustain these nipping passions which assalt me* with this the
miserable knight sent forth a scalding sigh, and by his countenance appeared to
be plunged in great sorrow, insomuch yt the ecko of his bitter passions moved
ye shiuering leaves to quietness, and the percing air to a certain calm stay,
only to hear ye plaints of this oppressed knight. In this heavy plight, and
woeful cogitation ye afflicted Grecian spent ye weary night, until the
glistring Sun with his radiant beams, did shine upon the green grass and
sweet budding trees, and moved the chirping birds with their golden lays to
warble forth their sugered tunes. At that present hour the knight of the Sun
brideled his horse, and without setting his foot in the stirop he mounted upon
him, leaving the raines on his neck, to the end he might go where best liked
him, he had not long iourneied but he was come near unto a river which ran
through the Forest, his horse being very dry entered into it, altogether
careless of the exceeding anguish wherein his Master was, whose mind was so
perplexed in considering his strange mishap, that he forgot where he was,
until the bubbeling of the Crystal water awaked his benumbed senses, and then
seeing himself in this golden stream, and gasing on every side he espied the
armor of the valiant Moore, which was chained for a monument unto a Pine apple
tree. The Prince stayed long in viewing them, greatly admiring at such an
adventure, and approaching more near, he might well discern by the head piece
that the armor belonged unto the Moore whom he had sought with great labor
and pain, which sight did greatly trouble his mind. And turning his horse to
see the strangeness of this misfortune, he saw the bloody alter where the
Moore had committed this sacrifice, and near unto it was annexed a goodly
grave closely couched by a lofty Pine, wherein was engraven certain vearses,
which when he perused he might perceive that they were compounded by his
brother, and when he ^ad by reading of them, gathered the sorrowful end that
the valiant Moore made, he could not so well govern his affection, but yt his
eyes distilled gushing streams of water, greatly deploring with himself the
froward fortune of so valiant a man, where by imbruing his hands in his own
blood had thereby eclipsed his former honor. Then greatly exclaiming against
the wretchedness of this world, and the looseness of the people, he did note
the solemn vow his brother made, and therewithal did remember the fruits
of his virtue, and thereupon desirous to join with him in travail, he did
ingraue with his dagger somewhat under the other Epitaph, these vearses that
follow.

Whose travail strange shall lead him to this place,
to view this shield and strong Tartarians grave:
That man I warn that he do not deface
the same, deuisde by Rosicle'er the brave.
Whose brothers blood the quarrel shall maintain,
Against such knights, that would this armor gain.
When he had written this, he walked up and down by the grave, and by chance
saw ye dagger wherewith ye Moore had killed himself, and taking it in his
hand, he said: Truly thou have great cause to lament, since that thou have been
the instrument to murder the best knight that ever ware armor, and in memory
hereof thou shall stay here, saying this, he lift up his arm and struck the
Dagger into the pine tree up to the hiltes, and without any more tariance he
took his horse and travailed on through a young grove, the night being very
close, till at length he repaired to one corner of the River, which was all
shadowed with the green branches of Pine apple trees, and not far from the
River, he discerned an old ruinous house, which was very ancient, and as it
seemed no man did inhabit it, and as he made thetherwarde, he heard the voice
of one which as he thought sang very sweetly, whereupon he rained his horse and
directed his way thither. Not far distant from a tree he saw a green armor
engraven with perfect gold very richly, and there was fast tied unto a bough of
ye same, a shield of fine steel, the field being green, wherein was portrayed
a Mermaide, which in shape seemed to be a Goddess of the seas. Likewise close
unto the shield, there was chained a rich helmet, which was very strong. It
might well be thought by the riches of the armor they appertained to some
valiant man, and also it seemed the time was long since they had been hanged
there, for that the washing of the water had wasted the brightness of the
color. The knight of the Sun with an earnest desire beheld them, and saw
the body of the Tree ingraued with this word Florisdama. And when he could by
no means understand the conceit hereof he became very pensive, and ballancing
to his mind the fortune that chanced to him in the Island of the wild Fairie:
heerevpon he imagined this other was not much different from it. The Grecian
dwelling in this dumpe, turning his eyes he saw that all the trees there a^outs
did carry the name of Florisdama, and in some places it was shortly written
with an F. and a D. It chanced also among those trees he spied a sword fast
chained, which by the dama^ king and bravery of it, might be gessed to belong
unto some worthy Knight. These things procured the Knight of the Sun to
imagine, that this Knight ended his days desperately, through the sweet
enticing baits of love, which thing drove the Knight of the Sun into a
greater maze then he was in before, and therewithal engendered a desire in him
to see the end of this adventure. The stearne of his ship being thus guyded by
a careful Pilot, he returned back to the place where he first heard the noise
of the instruments, and the farther passage he made, the shriller he might
hear the sound, whereupon he travailed so long, that with ease he might
perceive the sorrowful Knight touch his Lute, with a panting heart, and
sometime intermedled his music with a sweet voice and a pitiful dittie. The
knight of the Sun was greatly inclined to know him that bewailed so bitterly
his mishap. And hearing him begin to sing certain verses, he stood still. The
sorrowful Knight of the Forest, began in this sort.

O Direful death! when shall the hour be
so long desirde, for to dissolve my grief:
That this my corpse bereaved of breath by thee,
in Mistres praise my soul may find relief.
Oh Atrapos (in deserts where I pine,
And living, die) do thou my thread untwine.
O loathed life! oh most unhappy fate!
wherein I feel such force as none may bide.
Injurious Dame, (which broughtst me to this state)
thy cruel dealing plainly is espide:
Yet thus I deem, and so my self persuade,
My moan, no mirth unto thy heart has made.
But sure I fear my fortun is not so fair,
that I for thee should bitter death sustain:
Yet if it chance, this still shall be my praire,
that ere my end, I may thy sight attain.
Ay me poor wretch, my wish would work my woe.
Thy irefull face would cause my grief to grow.
What force I that? If God would give consent,
that thy white hands a while before I dye
Might comfort me, I should be well content,
whether with friendly or with frowning eye
Thou me beheldst: For, being traind to grief,
Till life be lost, I look for no relief.
But what avails me my vain desire?
too childish is this fond conceit of mine.
No hope can help to that which I require,
these deserts are unfit for one so fine.
Yet often times here me thinks thy face I see,
With mercy mixed, anon with cruelty.
And even as one which spectacles does wear
in eight parts cut, can have no perfect sight,
(In that from one, such sundry forms appear):
even so my fancy never falls out right.
For in my sleep I only shadows see,
When substance sweet is farthest of from me.
Sometimes I prove, and forth I put my hand,
and think to feel the thing I hope to find:
But then (alas) my dream I understand,
and torments fresh do newly vex my mind.
So that these trees as witness of my care,
To hear my plaints to silence them prepare.
The time I sing to ease my heavy heart,
conuerts in fine to former misery:
Ah cruel Dame, that I (without desert)
for loving thee, in country strange should die.
But what know I, that thou do this intend:
Heavens grant thy sight to me before mine end.
Here he ended this song, the Knight of the Sun gathering by his dittie the
wretchedness of his estate, he could not but acco^panie his pitiful music
with many streams of brackish tears renewing in his mind the old storms that
lately battered his breast. Whereupon he then alighted from his horse, (which
before he had not done) and with a soft pace he marched toward the old
ruinous house, where he saw a knight prostrate upon the ground all clad in
cloth of gold, which in truth was torn in many pieces, and perceiving the
Knight to be of a goodly stature and very well proportioned, and so young that
scarce might be seen any hair on his face, and therewithal so fair, that
the knight of the Sun never saw any one that might match him, he greatly
wondered. This enthralled knight having his eyes shut up, h^^ guished forth
trickeling tears so fast, that almost with bl^bbering he had dis^igured his
face. As the Knight of the Sun viewed all these things attentively, the young
forlorn man without opening his eyes, turned him upon the other side and
said, Oh Prince of Dacia, how much better were it for thee to die then to live
in this continual thraldom. The Grecian prince stood still to see if this
sorrowing knight would renew his plaintes, who immediately after with extreme
dolor began to say. Oh death, what do I feel, whether are thy forces fled,
why have thou now forsaken me, since at this present thy courtesy might favor
mine estate. Oh cruel Fortun^ (admit there be any*) art thou not satisfied
with tha^ injury which thou have already extended upon me: wilt ^hou needs
inioyne me to suffer more penance: make an end I say, of thy greedy desire,
make me not sometimes merry and more often sorry. When he had finished these
speeches, he began to slumber, and immediately with a sorrowing sigh he began to
say. Alas Fortune, how many things are there framed by thy hands, sweet in
all men's taste, and sour in my disgestion, pleasant to many, and bitter to me.
After this he took again his instrument, and with an harmonious stroke and
pitiful voice he sang these vearses.

O Heart more hard then Hircan Tiger fell!
and are more deaf then senseless troubled seas:
O causeless foe, whose rigor does excel!
to thee I yield, thy anger to appease:
Take tyrant wrathful, wreake of me thy fill,
That ending now, my grief remain not still.
My heavy cheer, and evil that is past,
my fainting voice, my case so comfortless,
Thou moandst not once, so merciless thou wast,
nor stirdst thy foot, to ease me in distress:
But time will come, when sorrow has me slain,
That thy repentance will increase thy pain.
Ah cruel, how can thou the love forget,
that each to other we in youth professed?
Which when I mind, full many a sigh I ^et,
for that was it which first bred my unrest:
And for the sweet, which then by thee I felt,
I find sharp sour, O most unjustly dealt.
Tell me wherein I have offended thee,
or when I slackt thy service any way:
Then how can thou so much unmindful be,
when often in secret thou to me would say:
That in my absence, Lucifer so bright,
Nor gladsome Phoebus once should give thee light.
I gone, thou vowest, the waters should not yield
their wonted solace, nor the pleasant Rose,
Or any flower of the fragrant feeld:
such love thou said, thou did on me repose.
Which was but small as now the end does try,
That thus distressed, thou sufferst me to dye.
Oh Gods of love, (if so there any be)
and you, of love that erst have felt the pain,
Or thou thy self, that thus afflictest me!
hear these my words, which hidden grief constrain:
Ere that my corpse be quite bereaud of breath,
Let me declare the cause of this my death.
You mountain Nymphs which in these deserts reign,
cease off your chase of savage beasts a while,
Prepare to see a heart oppressed with pain,
address your ears to hear my doleful style.
No strength, remorce, no work can work my weal,
Love in my heart so tyrantlike does deal.
O Driades, of lovers much adorde,
and gracious damsells, which in euenings fair
Your closets leave, with heavenly beauty stord,
and on your shoulders spread your golden hair,
Attend my plaints: and thou that made'st me thrall,
If thou have power, give speedy death withal.
Ye savage Bears in caves and dens that lie,
remain in peace if you my reasons hear:
And be not moved at my misery,
though too extreme my passions do appear.
Ye Mounts farewell, ye fragrant fields adieu,
And silver streams, high Jove still prosper you.
He finished his song with many a bitter sigh, and he was so windlesse with
sobbing, that he lay as it were in an ecstasy stretched upon the ground. The
Knight of the Sun entering into this ruinous lodge, finding the Gentleman in
this wretched estate, he began ne to behold the proportion of his face, and
with extreme dolor wept, as well in ballauncing his own passed misery with
this young knights, as also for that he verily reputed him to be his brother
Rosicleer, or else some near kinsman of his, for that in beauty and
strongnesse of body, he resembled him so much, yt there was but small
difference between them, saving only the beard. While the Grecian Prince was
beholding this sorrowful sight, the inthralled knight with a deep sigh
awaking, and seeing the Knight of the sun before him, he wondered what might
draw so comely a Knight unto so solitary a wood, and therewithal he reared
up his body, and sitting upon ye green grass, with many a drerie tear, he
beheld ye shape of the Knight of the sun, and enforcing himself to speak, he
said: Sir Knight, insomuch as fortune has directed you hather to accompany me
in this desert place, sit by me I pray you, and pardon my folly, in that you
have found me so disordered. The Prince without making any answer, sat
down as the Knight entreated him, being very desirous to know the end of
that adventure, and what cause made him demean so tragical a life, he being
set, he told the Knight, that the desire he had to understand the bark
vearses that were in the trees, and likewise to hear his sweet songs, which
so harmoniously he sang, moved him to forsake his way, and to repair to this
ruinous lodging, and therwithall made render of his service to the knight.
While the Prince delivered these speeches, the comfortless Knight was musing
with himself, what he might be, who by his comeliness appeared to be
valiant, and by his courtesy to be honorable, and therewithal was very
desirous to know what he was, and being somewhat stinged with the bitter
passions which he had already sustained he said.

Alas sir Knight, how little is the body touched with the doleful cares of
the heavy heart, and how slenderly now a days is the guerdon of a faithful
friend, as mine own experience can best relate it, so shall your courtesy
move me to impart the well spring of all my woe, and then I beseech you judge
how unworthily I am tormented, I cannot otherwise think but you will pity my
m^shaps with some sorrowing sighs, especially if at any time you have tasted
the bitter pills of love, and I promise you I would be heartely glad that it
might stand with your pleasure to make me acquainted with your name, to the end
I might know to whom I might disclose my wretched estate. The Prince made him
answer and said. I am son to the Emperor Trebatio of Greece, and am called
the Knight of the Sun, brother unto the renowned Rosicleer, whom you greatly
resemble, and be thus persuaded, that the sparks of love has kindled as many
glowing coals in me as in any other, and has left as deep impression of
sorrow in my poor heart as in any other Knight. Therefore Knight as I have
satisfied your request, so I pray you unfold to me the cause which makes you
live so pensive. In so doing, I will swear by the almighty God, I will
hazard my life to purchase your desired quietness. The Prince of Dacia which
had already heard of the prowess of the Knight of the Sun, heerewithall
began to shake off part of his martirdomes, and knowing the worthiness of the
knight, bowing down his body somewhat low he said. Although yt my mishap have been great in susteining such continual griefs, yet do I esteem it sle^der,
since yt heerby I have purchased acquaintance with ye flower of all chivalry,
whose valiant heart does bemone my oppressed estate, and whose only counsel will
determine my exceeding torments. Since the^ renowned prince ye love has already
made a passion in thine heart, whereby you may ye better be an eye witness of my
wretchedness, or to say the truth of my cruel death: Understand you then
that I am Don Eleno Prince of Dacia, son to Cadislao, brother to the high and
mighty Emperor Trebatio your Father, and to the beautiful Florisena Daughter
to the king of Cypres and Nygroponte, under whose wings I was nourished till I
was eight years of age, and was trained up in ye regal sort as was incident
to my parents estate. Being of this age, spightfull Fortune who is slipperie
to all men, and leuells commonly at the contented mind, spun me so course a
third, as I fear me in the weauing it will prove my utter destruction. This
blind Fortune I say, conuayed to the king my Father his court the beautiful
Princess Florisdama, daughter to the king of Nygroponte, brother to my Father,
she was equal to me in age, and so endued with beutie, that she seemed
Angelical. While I was thus young, the burning flames began to scorch me,
which now do singe me, and we were so allied, that without any suspicion we
walked where we would, and most commonly we spent our time in a banqueting
house which was half a mile from the City which was right fair, and
compassed about with christalline streams, and green meddowes furnished with
sweet flowers we lead so pleasant and princely a life, yt we bestowed all our
care in catching chirping Birds and young ^eauerets. Our mutual good wills
was so great, as seldom did we forbear each others company, mine proceeding
of an inward desire to have her to my wi^e, and hers in regard of the affinity
which was between us. This ^ugured life continued until we were fourteen
years of age, the which time we bestowed in hunting, to the great comfort of
my heart (though in the end not to the hearts ease of my mind) my Florisdama
having a crossebowe in her hand, and a bugle horn about her neck, little
mindful of that sorrow which galled me so much. While she continued this
vain in hunting, it begat a singular good will in me to see her shoot,
having her golden locks somewhat laid forth, and upon her head was knit a
garla^d of all sweet smelling flowers, she had a gown of white Satin all laid
over with gold lace, which made her seem so celestial, that she had been able
to have quailed the heart of Cupid. Believe me and doubt not of it, valiant
Prince, that Venus in her most bravery did never excel her. Neither could
the inchaunted Circ^s with all her cunning, frame so much beauty in her face,
to beguilde those whom she thought to entice. My desire still increased to
behold so much beauty, and the beautiful Lady settled all her care in
chasing the little Fawn, which when she had gotten at any advantage, she
would surely shoot and speed, whereupon I would speak softly unto my self and
say. Alas, that arrowe we^e better bestowed in my heart, for being once dead,
I should avoid an hourly death, which pearceth me every day. Therefore be
assured of this, Knight, that I sustained not so much joy by her company in
the ^aie time, but I endured as great torment in the night by her absence.
Being thus wasted in woe, Florisdama had a narrow scantling at the cause of
my passions, and yet was she not fully resolved that it was for her sake, and
therefore with making shows of love she demanded what wringed me in such
sort, either whether it was an imperfection in my self, or a want of boldness
to discover it, having as I have already declared attained to the age of
fourteen years, I was dubbed Knight by my father, God knows how grievous it
was to me to be separated from the thing wherein I ioyed so much. The
imagination whereof I refer to your discreet judgment, most worthy Grecian
Prince, since that already you have tasted the same sauce of cruel love, and
alas how grievous were those thoughts unto me which brought unto my mind the
enter-course of speech, the kind familiarity, the pleasant walks, and the
comely graces of my divine Florisdama, your passed misery may easily have an
ame at ye same, and my present estate may best discover it, what shall I say
more, right worthy knight, but my passions were so bitter, and my help so
slender, that I lost my color, forbear my meat, and grew to be so weak,
that an inkling thereof came unto my ladies ears, who perceiving in what poor
and low estate I remained, entreated me most earnestly to disclose unto her
the cause which pinched me so greatly, promising me that if my sorrows might
be relieved through the favor of any Gentlewoman, she would strain her
self to release them if it were possible, and would hazard her self to
procure her favor which had so much enthralled me, whereat with watrie eyes I
thus answered her.

Alas Florisdama, love has laid such a corsiue to my heart, such a flame
unto my lights, and such a sting unto my breast, as it has reduced me to
this state wherein you see me. Oh sovereign Lady, how much better had it
been for me, that rather in my green years and in the midst of my hunting,
Atrapos had shredde in sunder the twist of my life, then now to continue in
sorrow without any hope of release or delart of relief. The Angelical Lady
seeing me weep so heavily, could not but distill some few tears from her
christallin eyes, albeit she did not thoroughly feel the bottom^ of my inward
grief, and therevppon she said thus.

Ah my loving brother, let me obtain that favor as to manifest unto me the
cause why you fail in sorrow, and as it seems remodilesse, granting my
request, I promise you to procure with all diligence that there may be some
salve that may cure that festering wound which seems to cancur your heart and
impair your joys, for if you give me credit I am persuaded there is no Lady
so ungrateful as to deny you her love, being so valiant a Knight as you
seem to be: and again, knowing the worthiness of your progeny, the
disposition of your mind, and those incomperable virtues which shine in you:
Alas why should not the courage of your mind suffice to kindle the
