hand on his sword. And the Prince likewise was ready to discharge his blow,
who raising himself up in his stirrops, stroke so strong a blow upon the
pagans helm, that the sound was heard a great way in the fields, and it
enforced him whether he would or not to make reverence, and to hold down his
head being so astonyed, that it seemed a great tower had fallen upon him: and
as he would have setteled himself again in his saddle, he stroke him such
another upon his shield, that he drove it unto his head, which made him to
turn up the white of his eyes with the great grief which he received: and to
keep himself up from falling, both he and his horse staggered on the one
side, which made the Prince to loose many a blow, notwithstanding, he pressed
on him so fast, that he had no time to turn him to strike again. This Moore
was very much amazed at his great force and strength, and struck at the prince
so furious and strong a blow, that he made him to loose his understanding, and
almost to stoop with all his body upon his horse neck. The prince came
straight way to himself, and returned unto ye Moore with so much fury,
striking such a blow upon his shield, which although it seemed to be as hard as
a Diamond, yet for all that, he cut it in two pieces, and the blow descended
upon his sholder, with such a great weight, that the mountains eckoed with the
noise: which made the pagan for fear of falling to hold himself fast by the
Horse mane, very much marueling yt in one Knight there should be so much
strength. Then he threw from him the rest of his shield which was left, and
took his broad sword in both his hands, and drove such a blow at the Prince,
that lighting upon his visor, it deprived him of his sight, and forced him to
fall upon his horse neck without any remembrance. This stout Pagan would have
returned to strike him again, but he could not: for that his horse being
skarred with ye blow, lept on ye one side, which saved him from it. Yet ye
pagan followed to accomplish his will, which he could not do so speedely, but
that the Prince did settle himself in his saddle, and recovered again his
sword, and committing himself to God, as he always was accustomed to do, he
said: Oh holy Jesus for thy names sake, aid and help me. And therewith he
spurred his Cornerino with great fury, that he made him run like the wind,
and in his course he said, Tarry, tarry, thou man without faith, and do not
think that thy blows has done any other thing on me, but only caused my ire
and anger to increase the more, for to procure to bring thee to thy end, and
to send that excommunicated soul of thine to the devil: and in the running
of his horse, when he drew nigh him, he threatened him with his sword, shaking
of it in such sort, that he gave him to understand, that at the next blow he
would make an end of the battle: and therewith he stroke him such a blow on
his helm, that the blood ran out at the visor thereof, and he fell down
backwards upon his horse crouper almost dead. The great force that the Prince
gave to strike him, was the cause that he brake the lether of his right
stirrup, and therewith he fell to ye ground from his horse. But straight way
with great lightness he arose up again, and in the best manner he could he
made it fast, and leaping into the saddle, he returned toward his enemy:
who was with great trouble settling himself in his saddle, and looking up to
the heaven, he showed a pitiful countenance, as though he had been very sore
hurt, as in truth he was. And when he saw himself so ill entreated, and all
his head bathed in blood, he began to cry out against Mahomet saying. Oh
Mahomet, thou art the falsest God, amongst all the Gods, cursed be all they
that do trust in thee, and believe in thee. And of this be thou sure, that I
do not believe now in thee, neither will I so long as I live: and this I do
promise thee, that wheresoever I find any Temple or Image of thine, to break
them down with the strength of mine own hand and furious arm. And with this
anger he lift up his sword alofte, going toward the Prince, who was tarrying
for him in the same manner, and with like fury. And both together, they
discharged their heavy and terrible blows, but the Moors blow was the first
that lighted upon the knight of the Suns healme, so that it made him to
shake in his saddle, and he lacked but a little to fall down, the great
force and heaviness of that blow was the occasion that the blow of the
Prince could not be executed with the fury wherewith it was discharged, for
that peradventure if it had, he had not found himself so well as afterward
he did, for although it hit not right, being stricken with so much madness,
yet it made him whether he would or no, to stoop with his head, and therewith
he straight ways sett^led him, and seeing that the knight of the Sun was
still remaining in without any feeling, he said.

I do not determine to tarry any longer, for that as I do believe, thou art
none other but the God Mars (although thou have said that thou art a mortal
man as I am,) and that thou art come down to give me the order of
knighthoode, and afterward to make me feel the strength of thy arm, and when
he had said these words, he called his Lackyes in great have, and rode
away with as much speed as possible might be. At which time with the noise
of the battle came Tefereo, and as he saw the Prince in that sort, and his
enemy going away* with so much have, he made no longer tarrying, but set the
spurs unto his horse, and with a^ great swiftness as he could, he followed
after him. The Prince when he came again unto himself, and could not see
his enemy, was so kindeled with anger and wrath, that the blood ran out at
his eyes with very anger. This Mauritanian did very well in not tarrying the
fury of the Prince at that time, for with the wrath that he had, hard
Diamondes had not been able to have made any resistaunce against him,
wherefore he determined forthwith to follow after him, but that a Damsel
which was by, put her self before him and said.

Gentle Knight, it is sufficient that Tefereo does follow him, wherefore
venture not thy self a new in that wherein thou do get but very little
prowess, for he that does follow him; will handle him well enough, therefore
come and follow me, for that there is other matters of greater importance
which are tarrying for thee. The Prince when he heard these words beheld
well the Damsel that was talking with him, and straight ways he knew her to
be the Damsel that he and the Prince Eleno had found in the Bark, who after
these speeches went onwardes her way with great speed. The Prince at that
time had not his heart so quieted within him, as to ask her any questions, but
without saying any word he followed her, till they came unto the filde
whereas he saw the Bark wherein the Damsel had come thither, into the which
she entered, and after her followed the Knight of the Sun, but when they were
setteled within the Bark moved nothing at all, whereby they well understood
that it tarried for more company whom he thought to be for his friend
Tefereo, and as you before heard, he with great fury on horse back rode
after the Moore, and made so much* have in following him, that he ouertooke him
in a plain field, and at the great noise and calling that Tefereo made, this
Moorish king looked back, believing that it had been the Knight of the Sun,
but when he saw him and knew by his armor that it should not be he, he
tarryed for him, and when they drew nigh together, he said! Knight, what a
Devil would thou have, that with so great have thou do follow me, and
with so arrogant a voice do call me, Tefereo answered him and said.

Cowarde, to make thee pay the giving of that blow, which thou gave unto a
better Knight then thou art. Then the king said. Oh high Gods, what may this
be, that in the beginning of my knighthoode I should be so reui^ed, and unto
Tefereo he replied: Knight thou lie, for I never left my battle for
cowardnesse, but that as I do well know, he with whom I had battle is no
man, but a Devil, and again I l^fte him for that he gave unto me the order
of Knighthoode, but now thou shall pay for all that which he has done unto
me, jointly with the words which thou have here spoken, and without any
more tarrieng they began to strike many and unmeasurable (...) the one at the
other, the Moore stroke (...) at the Sardenian which was so terrible, that it
made him clean to loose his sight, and to lean on the one side of his horse,
so that he had almost fallen down, but with a ^rice he setteled himself
upright in his saddle again and finding the Moore at hand, (...) a thrust at
him so firm and strong, (...) thrust him clean out of the Saddle upon the
crouper of his horse^ so that he lacked but a little of falling down
backwarde, and seeing him in this sort, with wonderful agilitie he (...) on
the other side, and before that the Moore could settle himself well again,
he stroke him such another blow upon his healme, that he made him to reele
forwards as fast as he did backwardes, and then he doubled him another blow
upon the back, that whether he would or no, he made his head to touch the
buttocke of his horse, and with the great fury that he stroke the blow, he
pricked his horse, which was the occasion that he ran forwards in such
sort, that the Moore had time to recover himself* again, using his
accustomed cursinges against Mahomet, (...) calling him a thousand detestable
names. So these valiant warriors without any farther staring, joined again
together, whereas there began a new battle far more rigorous then the
first, for that they were both furiously incensed with anger, not ceasing to
torment their arms with terrible blows, without all pity, in such sort* that
their blows were delivered more with strength then with any policy. Thus
with terrible fury they bruised one another flesh, that either of them did
feel it very much: this Mauritanian with great fury lift up his swoorde for
to strike the Sardenian, and he placed it in such sort that he made him to fall
upon his horse crouper, but by reason of the great fury wherewith it was
discharged, and again that the Moors horse was somewhat weary, he stumbled
and bowed upon his knees, in such sort, that in a great while he could not rise
up again, and although he spurred him very much, yet it (...) The Moore seeing
that all that he could do was to little effect, cried out against Mahomet,
and with the great force that the Moore used, his horse arose again upon his
feet, at such time as the Sardenian with so outrageous cholar, that the smoke
flew out at his visour, took his great sword in both his hands, letting his
sheelde hang at his back, and stroke him such a terrible blow upon the creast
of his helm, that he made him clean to loose his feeling for a great while.
The Moors horse by reason of his weariness was ready to fall down on every
side: This valiant Sardenian seeing him in that case, and remembering in what
order he had before left the knight of the Sun, without any more tarrying
turned about his swift and light horse, and with as much swiftness as might
be possible, he returned unto the place where as he had left the knight of the
Sun and when he came unto the place whereas the battle was fought between the
two warriors, he found not the knight of the Sun there, but retourning back
again he took his way toward the Sea side, following the foot steps of
them and their horses, and in a small time he came unto the place, whereas he
saw a bark which was at an anchor fast upon the shore, and coming nigh unto
it he knew it to be the very same which had brought them thither, and for to
know of certainty whether the knight of the Sun were there or not, he
called with a loud voice unto them which were in the Bark: unto whom the
Greek made answer, and when he saw that it was his friend Tefereo that had
called, he was very glad, and likewise Tefereo did greatly rejoice to see
him, and therewith he entered into the Bark, and when he was entered therein,
he heard one with a loud voice, which said. Tarry, tarry, thou cowardly
villain, and do not think to escape me without thy due punishment. At which
great noise the Knight of the Sun looked about and saw that it was the King
of Mauritania, which with very great have came toward them. The Prince would
have gone out to him if yt the Bark had not ben so far in the sea, as it was,
for the which he was very sad, and not a little disquieted, yet for all the
anger which the Prince had, he could not choose but say that the king was a
good knight, and of as much might as Bramarant, and somewhat more valiant and
politic, and meruailed with himself whether he were his son or no. So when
the Pagan saw that he could not execute his fury and rage, he began to
roar like a Bull, and although he was not purposed any more to imbarke
himself to sea, yet at that time he was constrained to change his pretense,
and finding opportunity by reason of certain Merchauntes which were
fraighting of a ship to Grecia, he determined to go into her. There he
embarked himself, and the wind being very prosperous they departed, and in
a very short time they arrived at a haven in Grecia, where as he went a land,
and travailed in the Country certain days. So it happened one day that he
found by a house of pleasure, a great company of Knights, Ladies, and
Damosells, which were recreating of themselves. What they were, and what the
king did, in following the Story you shall understand, and I will now leave
him for to tell you of the heroycall son of Trebatio, who for the space of
six days sailed on the Sea with great pleasure, often talking of the great
strength and force of the Moore, the seventh day he arrived in a very fair
haven or port, which was nigh unto a very sumptuous City, the which was
furnished with great ships and Gallyes, and other small Barks and Foystes.
Amongst all these they passed very quicklye, without the interruption of any
person, till such time as the Bark was fast a ground, and perceiving that it
was there convenient that they should disimbarke themselves, they leapt a
shore, and likewise took out their horses, and straight way they leapt on
their backs, and took the way which lead them unto the City, wherein they
discovered on the one part a very fair and great army of men, and likewise
all the field was pitched with very rich Tents, and as they looked about,
straight ways they saw come forth of the City five mighty and strong
Knights, and a very great and strong Gyaunt, and in the other part of the
army one only knight, whose armor seemed to be of a passing fine Rubie, all
to be spotted with stars of gold, and set with Pearls. This sight did like
them so well, that they were looking on that one Knight a great while very
earnestly, and took great pleasure to see his good demenour. The Knight of
the Sun was imagining with himself what knight that should be, that was of
so gentle disposition and proportion, believing certainly that it could be
none, but some of his lignage. This knight passed hard by those two friends,
who did behold them very much, yet he made no staying, but without speaking
any word he passed on forwards, and when he was come into that place of the
field that was appointed for the battle, he put his spear in his reast, at
the which token one of the six knights came forth to make resistaunce, whom
the knight of the Sun did know.

But now for that the history goes in order, it is needful to leave them in
this order, till time shall serve, and to return again, and tell you of the
Emperor of Grecia, that came to the port of Cimarra, and there did disimbarke
himself.

How the Greek Emperor did disimbarke himself at the City of Cimarra, and
what happened unto him there. Cap. 25.
YOU have heard before how that the Emperor arrived at the Port of Cimarra,
which was governed by the Father of that unfortunate Herea, where when he
had put in order his inchaunted Bark, he leapte a land, and going on foot
armed with that rich armor which Garrofilea had given unto him, carrying his
right hand upon the reast which was in his armor, and his left hand voon the
pomell of his swoorde, and his helm close which covered his face, and hanging
at his neck his gallaunt and rich sheelde, with a comelye and grave
countenance he went toward the City, and of the first that he met withal,
he asked what land or Country that was, for that he was ignorant thereof,
and straight way it was told him in the Sarasin language, that he was in the
kingdom of Cimarra, whereat he was not a little delighted, and considering
the knowledge of the wise Lyrgandeo, he went forwards on his way without
staying, till he entered into the gates of the City, and all they which met
with him, did very much behold him, greatly meruailing at his gravity, good
disposition, and wonderful stature. There were sundry that advertised the
King thereof as soon as he was come a shore, how that there was a knight
which did disimbarke himself at the Port or Haven, which came without
government, being armed with very rich and costly armor, and one that was
of an excellent stature and good disposition. The ancient King of the Country
who was advertised thereof before by the wise Lyrgandeo, did straight way
know that it was he which had passed the terrible keepers of his murdered
Daughter.

For you shall understand, that as soon as the Emperor was departed from the
Island, the wise Lyrgandeo commanded that the body of the Lady should be
carried unto Cimarra, aduertising her Father, that the long looked for
reuengement was not far of. And likewise how and in what manner the knight
which did it should come into his land, and also who that Knight should be.
Wherefore as soon as the king was given to understand of his ariuall, without
any more tarrying, being accompanied with all his noble men, and leading in
his hand a very fair and young child, about twelve years old; the most
best proportoined that ever nature could frame, of whom you shall hear no
more in this book, for that in the second book it shall be declared at
large of him. The king went forth till he came to the chief place of the
City, there to meet with the Emperor, whereas likewise he met with this old
and ancient King, who boowing his knees to the earth, and shedding of many
tears, with joy, received him, saying. O high and mighty Emperor, give me
here your hands, that I may discharge the duty that all humane creatures do
owe unto your highness: how much more I, that am bound thereunto, for that
with so much firmness thou would confirm thy oath, and take the charge in
thine own person to work my reuengement. The Emperor was in a great
confusion, to hear himself named, and never gave any in all that land to
understand thereof, but straight way he suspected, that Lirgandeo should
advise him of his coming. And heerewith using of his accustomed bounty, he
took him by the hand, and lifted him from the ground, saying, Good King, the
debt which thou say is due unto me, thou have repayed in showing the
nobleness of thy heart and courage, and otherwise I am constrained by ye order
of knighthood and justice, to make reuengement of that cursed fact, which was
without all pity committed upon thy daughter. And seeing that there can be no
other remedy but only reuengement, here of my part I do offer thee to do
all, that in my power is possible to be done, desiring thee that thou restrain
these tears, and give order that with great speed there may be joined
together all thy power, to the end that we may go and conclude that which in
me lies. The King with a sad voice answered. High and mighty Emperor, this
has been provided for before, for all my people and shires are at an hours
warning, to go to the ayding of so just a cause, and we tarryed for nothing
but only your royal person, who must be the sword of my reuengement.

Thus with these and such like communications, they went unto the Kings
pallaice, which was hanged all with black clothes, for others he would not
consent to have hanged, since the death of his daughter Herea. There was the
Emperor unarmed, and served with as great highness and honor, as though he
had been in Grecia. Notwithstanding the Emperor, would not soiourne nor rest
there much, for the next day in the morning he commanded that all the people
should march forwards unto a haven which was at the uttermost parts of all the
Kingdom, whereas they found ships and barks of all sorts, very well
furnished of all things that was needful. There was three hundred ships one
with another, in the which there was embarked fifty thousand Moors
meruailously well appointed, and committing their sails unto the wind, all
this Navy took their voyage toward Numidia. So they nauigated, and founds
the wind favorable, which brought them unto a port or haven, which was but
two leagues from the Kings house. There, with great joy and pleasure they went
a shore, with out any resistaunce or gainsaying. So when they were all out of
the ships a land, they displayed their ancients, and in very good order they
marched forwards. And at such time as Apollo had made an end of his journey,
and that the dark night came on, they came in sight of the City, and without
taking any rest, toward the land side they pitched their tents, and fortified
themselves in the best wise they could, in such sort, as their good Captain
which did govern them had commanded, without doing any thing to the
contrary. So when all things was put in good order as they would have it, he
commanded that all the army, should go unto the gate of the City that was
most nearest, the which was straight way done: and in three days after they
did no other thing but ease and rest themselves: for that the people were
somewhat out of quiet with their great travail.

The fourth day, the Emperor seeing that there was no sturring in the City,
(the which was done by policy, tarying to see what the enemies would do) the
Emperor called for his armor: and being armed, there was brought a very
fair and mighty horse unto him: and with his accustomed courage he issued out
from amongst his company, and rode toward the wall of the City, and put
himself into a fair green plain nigh unto the walls, and lifting up the
visour of his healme, he set his horn unto his mouth, and did sound it very
strongly, which was to warn them that were in the City, to come to the walls
and harken what he would say: and when he saw that there was much people,
attending to hear him, he began to say. O King Noraldino of Numidia, how
careless thou art in this thy strong country, thinking that the strength
thereof will defend thee, that thou payest not the price of thy naughty
treason, which thou did use with that unfortunate Herea. Take unto thee thy
armor, and for that thou had a heart to commit this evil deed, have now
likewise a courage to make thy defense: come forth of these thy walls, thou
traitor, and destroyer of the royal blood. All they which were on the walls
did hear the threatenings, and straight way went and told it unto the king
of Numidia, who was at that time in communication of wars and of armies, and
of all things that belonged thereunto, and when he heard these news, giving a
great sigh he said. Oh ye Gods, are not you content to see me in this
perplexity, and so much wronged, but likewise with sound of trumpet suffer me
to be outraged in calling me traitor. These feigned griefs and sorrowful words
had so much force, that it moved the hearts of the Princes that were with him,
for to go out into the field for his defense: and in great have they
commanded, that their harness should be brought unto them, with determination
to dye, or to defend his cause. And there was none that had any fear, but
only the Giant, for that he would not give any credit unto the Kings words,
although he dissembled never so muuch: but by reason that he had sworn
thereunto, he was constrained by his oath to go forth with the rest.

So in this order as I have told you, they went forth of the City all six
together: and he which gave the first onset was that valiant and amorous Eleno
of Dacia brothers son unto the Emperor, who with a gentle behavior when he
came nigh the Emperor, said in the Saracen tongue: It is not the part of good
Knights to speak any villainy, especially against Kings whom they are bound to
have in reverence and honor. To whom the Emperor answered in the same
language. Art thou Noraldino King of Numidia? Don Eleno replied, No, but I am a
Knight, and a very stranger in this country: but yet by firm oath, I
determine to dye in the defense of his right. The Emperor answered: He has
neither justice nor right on his side, but it is most apparent wrong which he
does maintain, and there is no reason that such a traitor as he is, should be
by any other defended: neither is it seemly that any Knight of price should
charge himself in his behalf, for that he is a traitor. And likewise he that
does defend him and take his part (in this, that he will sustain and
maintain so great injustice) is pertaker of his treason, and meriteth a
traitors name. And for that thou art his defender, here I give thee to
understand, that I care not for thee, and less I do esteem thee: for that
he which does take upon him to defend a traitor, may well be accounted a
traitor. This valiant Eleno, when he saw himself to be so ill entreated,
answered: Thou lie in so saying, for that I was never traitor, neither do I
proceed of the lynage where traitors ever were: notwithstanding, thou shall
pay me with thy head, the great vncurtesie which thou have used unto me.
Therefore it does stand thee in hand to look unto thy self, and take that
part of the field which thou think best for thy purpose, and leave off
these blazing words to join with me in battle, that I may see if thou can
as well defend thy quarrel, as thou can handle thy tongue. At which words,
there drew nigh them the Prince Clauerindo, and as the Emperor would have
departed to put himself in battle, he did behold him, and straight way knew
him. And casting his eyes on the one side, likewise knew the other three, but
he could not know who the Prince Eleno should be: and for the great desire
which he had to know what he was, he said: Knight, I do desire thee for
courtesies sake to tell me what thou art: and if thou will not grant me this,
then I pray thee to lift up y^ visor of thy helm, y^ I may see thy face? for
here I give thee to understand thy four companions I do know, which is the
occasion that I have no desire to enter into battle with thee. Then Don Eleno
answered and said: Pagan, of the two things which thou do ask of me
(although there is no compulsion) yet will I pleasure thee in fulfilling one of
them: and in saying these words, he lift up the visour of his healme, and when
the Emperor saw him, he believed that it had been his son Rosicleer, and
with a loud voice he said. Oh mighty God, how can this be true, that unto
knights of my lignage should chance so vile a spot, who hitherto in all their
doings have got great honor and praise, and now are come to defend such
apparaunt wickedness and treason. Thou shall understand knight, that I am the
Emperor Trebatio, and would not willingly now be called thy Father, for that
thou art come to defend so apparaunt and known an evil, for I knowing the
unreasonable naughtiness that this king has committed, am come to take this
conquest in hand, for in all my life time I never took a more iuster cause in
hand, neither was there ever in all the world a thing more worthier of
punishment then this, and seeing that my fortune has been such, that my first
enemy that should come against me, seems my son, put thy self here now
before thy high progenitour from whence thou do descend, and for Gods love
do not blot thy stock, in defending traitors and treason, and therewith in few
words he told unto them all the whole history, as before I have told you. Then
this excellent Dacian answered. High and mighty Emperor, although by my name
thou have not known me, yet in calling me son thou did happen on the
truth. For thou shall understand that I am called Eleno of Dacia, son unto
the king of Dacia thy brother, and in that which thou have said that we do
maintain treasons, we are to the contrary informed, nevertheless I beseech
your highness to tarry here a while, and therewith he and the Prince in a
great confusion returned to the place whereas the rest of his companions were,
and turning his talk unto the king, he said. King of Numidia, thou shall
understand that yonder knight is the Emperor of Grecia, my uncle, who in that
small time which we have been with him, has told unto us all the effect of this
thy matter, clean contrary unto that which thou have declared unto us.
Therefore King, there is no reason, that Knights of so high blood and name as we
are should be set to defend lies and treasons: but if it be to the contrary of
that which he has told unto me, have no doubt but tell us the truth. For here
I swear by the love that I bear unto that unloving Lidia, that I will
travail so with my uncle, that greatly with thy honor thou shall go
thorough with this conquest. Then this false King answered. O Knights which
do confess your selves to be Christians, and by the God whom you do worship
have made a solemn oath to help and defend me by the strength of your arms:
how happens it now y^ without any care of your oath, which you have sworn, you
will leave me desolate, and go from your words, being doubtful of the very
truth. The courageous French man answered: Do thou not think King, that our
oaths and words shall be abrogated, rather first we will leese our lives, both
I, the prince, and all our companions: but consider king, that God will not
that we shall imagine amiss of Trebatio, who is a prince of great verity and
truth, and again, our very nigh kinsman. Therefore this, and that which he
has told us, has moved us to come and tell thee, and do say, that none of
us will go from his word and oath if thy cause be just. Then the valiant
Eleno did cut off his reasons, and tourning unto the King he said. King of
Numidia, here I do most humblye desire thee, that with false illusions thou
put not us unto so great travail, for that then it can not be, but either
we must dye in the hands of him whom we do desire to serve, or else, (though
far unlikely) to kill him. Is it possible king, that thou have brought us
unto this estate, that cruelty should govern our wills, without having power
to do any other thing. The King when he saw that the Knights were very
earnest, began to swear with great oaths that his cause was just, and that he
had told unto them the truth of the matter, and if so be that the Emperor had
told them any other thing, it was only to deceive them, and to turn them,
that they should not make his defense, and charged them again with their oath
which they had made and how that they had given their words to be his vpholder
and defender. This worthy Dacian tourning unto his companions said. Knights,
what do you think in this matter, what is it best that we do herein? For
well you do see, that we are so bewrapte and bound one against another, and
cousin against cousin, yet for all that we cannot by any means excuse the
battle. So they did all determine to return unto the Emperor, and to
desire him for to accept it in good part, and to leave off that battle, and
to make the^ believe that he was falsely informed, and when they came unto him
they said. Worthy Emperor, and our only Lord, look well unto this false
information, wherewith they have informed you, and having well considered
thereof, we do all request you, for the love which unto your sons and
cousins, and unto all your friends you do owe, that it may move you to take
no occasion to put us into this extremity, for that by any means we cannot
go from our oath and word. Unto the which the Emperor answered and said. My
loving friends, if that you have given your word and oath to procure to make
defense of so false a King, do you likewise endeavor to perform the same: for
the like will I do to accomplish that which I have promised, for that there is
no more reason for the one then for the other. But this one thing I do tell
you, that it is very apparent that you will maintain the treason of this false
King, as it appears plainly by many reasons, which I have told unto you: and
the principal cause, wherein you may see plainly his treason and falshoode,
is the little have that he does make himself unto the battle, and if he
knew that he doo^h maintain the truth, let him come forth and make his own
defense. At the which reasons they all held their peace, considering the great
reason which the Emperor had declared, and determined that the next day they
would conclude, what were best to be done, and so these six knights returned
unto the City, and the Emperor unto the camp. Of all this that happened, he
that received the most contentment, was the Prince Eleno, for he desired very
much to return unto the City, for that at his departure he left his Lady
very sick, so that he thought not to find her alive, and coming to the
City, he was no sooner alighted from his horse, but he went straight unto
her Chamber, whereas he found her with a mighty burning ague, and seeing her
in that case, he was as one that was beside himself, and the more that her
ague increased, the more furious she did show her self and farther out of
quiet. So this grievous and sick Lady did ask paper and ink for to write a
few lines unto him which was the causer of all this her harm, and making an
end of her writing, without power to do any other thing, with the great
feebleness she felt, she fell down upon her pillowe, and speaking unto Eleno
she said. Ualiant knight, behold here thy Lidia, at her last end: for that
there does not remain in me strength for to give thee thanks, for so great
benefits as I have received at thy hands: yet I carry one great comfort with
me, which is, y^ although I dye, yet thy great loyalty does not dye, neither
my firm faith, and although I was vnloued of an unfaithful Knight, yet am I
beloved of the most courageous knight in the world. This sorrowful and
troubled Prince would not suffer her to go forwards with her talk, but with
shedding of many tears from his eyes, he said.

Oh my sweet Mistress, do not give me to understand that thou will dye, if
that thou mean I shall remain alive. Oh my love, I would rather that my heart
should be parted in twain, by the greatest enemy that I have, then to
remain without thee. Oh my loving Mistres, let this thy youthful years and
great beauty which thou have, encourage thee, and die not in this order: this
feeble Lidia for to show with more feruentnesse the good will which she did owe
unto the P^^^ce, for his great courtesy forced her self to hold up her head,
and he lifted it up with such quickness, as though her weak members had felt
no grief, and as though the fury of that burning ague was not able to resist
her, but with the force of love she sat up in her be^, and with her face of a
fiery color she said. My Lord, time does not give me any place, that with
words I might gratify the great courtesy that of thee I have received: for
that I do feel, that the hour is come, and that the three fatal sisters
have the thread of my life between the edges of their sheeres, so that it
lacks nothing but to put them together: insomuch, that I miserable creature
do feel my soul tremble in my flesh, at this my last hour. But one thing,
(oh my sweet and true lover) I will desire thee before that I do dye, which
is, that thou would procure, that this letter may be given unto that
cruel Knight, who has brought me unto this estate, giving him to understand
of this my troublesome death, the occasion whereof, was his unreasonable
cruelty. And making an end of saying this, this miserable Lady fell down,
without having any more strength to sit up, but let the letter fall out of her
hand before her true lover, who took it up and said.

Oh all my joy, what a cruel knife is this to my heart, to hear thy
complayntes, in giving me to understand the great cruelty that love has used
against thee, without any desert or reason: and verily I do believe, that
these thy great thoughts and griefs, but most of all thy absence will be the
occasion of my death. And if y^ my enemies are not of power to give it me,
here I do swear unto thee by the great and true love which I bear unto
thee, that I my self with my own hands will procure to pull this heart out of
his place, for that it knew not how to give thee contentment paying therewith ye
duty yt I ow unto thee. O happy Brenio that did obtain so much grace and
favor at Venus hands, for to be beloved of the flower of all beauty. The
Clime in the which thou were borne was not so happy as to the contrary my
Clime has been unhappy and unfortunate. Take a good heart my Mistres, comfort
your self and be strong, and be not the occasion that I seek my own death,
and here I do promise thee by thy unhappy success, to bring thee into the
Province of Lusitania, or else to die.

Then this weak Lidia said: Gentle Knight, there is now no time all being
past, for that I do feel my self that this is the last fight. The sacred
Gods will not permit, that before my death I should see his face: for if I
did, I verily believe that I should receive some comfort. O immortal Gods,
into your divine bosoms I do commend my soul, asking no other reuengement
against the causer of all my evil, but that he die of the same infirmity.
And thou mighty Greek, here I do desire thee by the love which thou do
seem to owe me, for that thou see that my death cannot be excused, and that
Proserpina, is tarrying for me, with both her arms abroad for to receive my
soul. And again, that this shall be the last request that by me shall be
demanded of thee, as also to verify this love which thou have showed unto me
to be true, so that I hope thou can not by any means deny me to do it.
How is it possible my sweet Mistres, said the Prince, that now thou art in
doubt of my love, I promise you that my true love does not deserve this
suspicion, and here I give you to understand, that first the mighty river of
Tigris shall forsake her course and run back again, before that any lack
shall be found in me of that I owe unto thy love, neither any forgetfulness
to be the occasion to withdraw me from doing any thing that you shall
command me, therefore sweet mistres ask what your pleasure is, for that thou
can ask nothing at my hands, but it shall be all thine. This weak Lady,
whose power and strength was wholly decayed, and that her hour drew nigh at
hand, with a weak and feeble voice she said. That which I desire, gentle
Lord, is, that this my letter may come unto the hands of Brenio, wherein he
may see how cruel he has been unto his Lidia. So this dead Lady spoke never
a word more, for at that instaunt the destinies concluded to cut the third of
her life a sunder. Here the Prince lacked both reason and patience, here he
lost all his comfort and understanding, and coming unto the dead body of
Lidia, he fell in a sound, and when (by the procurement of the Ladies and
Damsells that were there present) he came to himself, he arose up with a
furious wrath, saying: Is it of truth sweet soul that thou art departed and
gone without me? Is it possible my Lidia yt I shall not follow thee whether
thou do go? Alas what shall I do? where am I y^ I do consent to let thee
depart alone? how is this my only love, shall I loose thee? What is it yt this
cruel heart aileth, that it renteth not in pieces. O Eleno is this the love
that unto thy Lidia living thou did show. At which great noise the other
four Princes entered into the chamber, who were meruailously altered to hear
his lamentations. So either of them in the best wise he could did procure to
comfort him, but this amorous knight with the great anguish that he had, fell in
a sound in the arms of Clauerindo, who requested the Ladies and damsells which
were there in company with the dead body, that they would ordain some thing
to bring him again to his remembrance, and so with such remedies as they did
make he came again unto himself, who then with great rage crieng out, called
for his Lidia. Oh my Lidia, what is become of thee, who for love in another
man's arms did die, and now I die for thy love? Oh the whole stay of all my
life, where art thou my Lidia, my comfort, do thou hear me? Do thou not
carry with thee this thy heart? No, no, for yet I do feel it. Is it possible
that I can live, or life will long sustain me? I hardly believe it. Oh my joy,
do thou come again, I pray thee be not so ungrateful, but stay a while
for I will come unto thee. For now I am certainly persuaded that I am
altogether without life. Fond Eleno if thou be dead, wherefore do thou talk
so much of vanities, wherefore do thou not hold thy peace. And with these
and such like reasons he remained without any feeling, in such sort that it
seemed that he was dead.

The other Princes which were there present seeing him in that case, took him
between them, and carried him unto another chamber, and procured that Lidia
should be buried, which straight way was done, for that the King commanded
his Sepulcher should be open, in which they put this dead Lady. The Prince
of Hungaria did remain in company with the Prince Eleno, for that he would
not let him alone, for he loved him out of all measure, because he did
resemble so much the valiant Rosicleer. So he remained there till such time
as he came unto himself, and the first word that Prince Eleno said, was:
Where is the Letter of my Lidia. Liriamandro did give it him, who taking it in
his hand, he said.

Oh work, and the last work of that white Iuorie hand: here I do swear
unto thee by the honor that I do owe unto knighthoode, not to a part it from
my heart, till such time as the heart of that cruel Brenio be cut it pieces,
and in speaking this he kissed it a thousand times, uttering a thousand
varieties. And straight way with a furious anger, he arose up and said: What
is this Eleno, do thou believe that with lamenting thou shall recover thy
well-beloved Lidia, and not perform that which by her was commanded thee. It is
more requisite that thou do travail and wander, till such time as thou have
performed that which thou have promised, gather unto thy self strength and
courage, for to perform that which thy heart is bound to do. So with this
anguish he arose up at such times as Aurora, with his glistering beams had
spread over the earth.

How that Eleno before he would go into the field, would see the Sepulcher of
Lidia, and what chanced in the battle appointed with the Emperor, his
kinsmen and friends. Chap. 26.
THE next morning when the day was come, all these stout warriors were ready
on horse back, but Prince Eleno, would first go and see the Sepulcher of his
Lidia, and going into the Temple of Mahomet, he went straight unto the place
whereas they told him that his Lidia was, and having no strength to suffer the
great grief that his heart did feel, he said. Oh my sweet Lidia, if thou
do hear my grief and lamentation, let it appear by some outward show in
these hard stones, which has bewrapt and enclosed thy white and delicate
body, that receiving grief at these my lamentations, it may give place that I
may see thee, let this my anguish grieve thee my Lidia, likewise let this my
misfortune grieve thee. But alas what shall I say, is it not sufficient that
the great pain that I do sustain for thy death, but I must bewail my own
sorrow: Oh mistres, at thy death thou made an end of all thy pains, and
mine does more and more increase. And in saying these and such like
lamentations, he drew out his Dagger, and with the point he wrote an Epitaph,
which was as follows.

Here Lidia lou'de and vnbelou'de does lie,
Whose great good will to her small good did bring:
She love did feel, which causeless did apply
to her (perforce) of death the bitter sting.
And though her corpse enclosed here does lie,
her lucklesse fate and fame will never die.
So when he had made this Epitaph, he arose up, saying: here I do promise
thee Lidia, since my fortune is such that I have lost thee, there is no other
that shall enter into this my heart and hard breast. But how can I say that it
is hard, did it not open at the hour when it felt thy absence, and so without
saying any more, he went out of the temple, with all the rest of his
companions, and taking their horses, they altogether issued out of the city,
at such time as the Emperor was arming himself in his rich tent. The fierce
king of Sardenia when he saw that they returned again, unto y^ which the day
before they did entreat of, he could not be in quiet, but said. O king, that
for the defense of thy person we must contend with that man whom we most
esteem, and thou must remain in the field only for the show of a knight, and
we enforced to finish the harm, whereof thou art the occasion. Well, do not
thou think that it shall be so, but persuade thy self, that thou shall be the
first in the encounter, that thou may prove how evil it is to suffer the
^urie of the Emperor of Grecia. O worthy king of Sardenia, answered the king
of Numidia, how the great affection which thou have unto the Emperor, does
cause thee not to give credit unto this my justice and right. Here I do
require thee by the oath which thou made unto me, that thou be the first to
put thy self in the defense of my person. To which the Sardenian answered:
First, the heaven and the earth shall join together, before that I will consent
that my arm shall move it self against him, whom I take for my Lord and
master. And here I say unto thee oh king, that if thou dooest but once again
will me heereto, I swear to thee by the sovereign God, that neither thy
power, nor all thy subjects shall be able to deliver thee out of my hands. So
their communication was cut off by seeing the Emperor to come toward them
upon a very fair horse, who showed so great fury, that it was a wonder to
see. At this present time there appeared coming from those parts which was
toward the sea, two Knights, who were very well armed. If you do remember,
these were the two valiant warriors, the prince of the Sun, and the strong
Sardenian. The great desire that the Emperor had to see himself with the
Numidian, was the occasion that he little esteemed the tarrying for those two
knights, for that he thought the hour was come of the battle, and that the
defender should be (as he had demanded) that false King and traitor, he put
himself forwards toward the place whereas the Princes and the king came. And
when they were together, these Princes with very fair and amorous words and of
great fidelity, endeavored so persuade the Emperor for to leave the battle,
and that therein they should receive marvelous great contentment, if he would
accept it. The knight of y^ sun stood and did behold their reasonings, and
did look for no other thing but furious battle, by all tokens yt they showed
with their hands and other demeanors of their bodies: and knowing five of the
knights, he very much meruailed what should be the occasion, and with this
desire he had to know what should move them to this controversy, he saw a
Lackie which passed by, and he called him, and asked of him in the Saracen
tongue, saying: Friend, tell me if thou cannest what is the occason that does
cause them to make this cruel and furious battle, and who they be that do
make it. This Lackie (by the riches of his armor, and by his good proportion)
judged him to be a knight of estimation, he said: Gentle Knight, the cause of
this controversy and defense, if I should stand to tell you it all, it would
be very tedious, but of all the rest that thou do ask me, I will give thee
to understand that which I do know. You shall understand that the knight
which is alone is the mighty Emperor Trebatio of Greece, and that which he
does maintain is great justice and right, and will give great punishment for
the same, which is that that the others do defend. The knight of the Sun was
very much amazed at that which he heard, and therewith he went toward them
before they had made an end of their reasoning* and so without any show of
trouble he said unto the Prince of Dacia (who was still sore troubled with the
sorrow, as you have heard). Art thou Don Eleno of Dacia, my cousin, and
brothers son unto the Emperor, my Lord and Father? I am he answered the
Dacian, who ought not for to dye, before I give thee thy death, for that thou
have caused so much evil to come upon me, that living I do now die. The
knight of the Sun being almost in a confusion to bear his dry reasons,
answered: Loving cousin, I feel my self somewhat troubled at these thy
words, and greatly amazed that thou art fallen into so great pride to lift up
thy armed hand against thy natural parents, and more being informed, that
which thou do pretend to defend is apparent treason. The Prince Eleno did
cut of his talk and said. Oh my cousin, here I do tell thee, that I do
seek no other thing but death, therefore procure to give it me, for that I
shall think my self happy to die in thy hands, notwithstanding defend thy
self as thou were wont to do, for that thou know it does so behooue thee.
With this fury and forgetful understanding, speking no more words, he turned
about his horse, crying out and saying: I will live no longer, seeing I have
lost that, beside which, to me can be no greater loss. The knight of the Sun
very much meruailed at these his short reasons, not knowing of any thing that
had happened unto him, and wondering that his true heart should commit or
maintain such wrongs, he turned about his horse for to make his defense, in
such sort, that all the knights that were there, were not sufficient to
disturb him, but with great fury they met together with their spears, yet not
one of the^ was moved in their saddles, but remained as though they had been
two towers, and straight way with no less force they began to lay hold on
their swords, and for that the knight of the Sun had a respect unto him, he
did rather procure to make his defense, then in any thing to offend him, but
Don Eleno stroke such a blow at his cousin, that he made him to stoop with
all his body to the horse neck. The knight of the Sun would have taken
reuengement of the same blow, but he considered that he was his cousin, and
that he was ignorant of the cause that should move him to commit this folly,
for the which consideration he did suffer him, and would make no reuengement.
Tefereo who saw all that had passed, and remained in his first place without
removing, til time did serve him to accomplish that which he had determined in
his mind to do, and when he saw occasion for the same, he threw his sheeld
upon his arm, and put his spear in his rest, and made a show yt he would be
doing with ye giant, yt which he perceived, and he put himself in a readiness,
but more to give him to understand what he was, then to hurt him. This furious
Sardenian stroke his horse with the spurs, yt he made him run like the commet
which falls from the side of Trion, and when he came in the midst of his
course, he turned his horse toward the place whereas the king of Numidia was
(who had put himself a part from the rest) with so great swiftness yt by no
means he could keep or defend himself from yt encounter, but by reason of
the strength wherewith it was given he threw them to the ground, very evil
entreated. He was no sooner fallen when that this courageous Sardenian leapt
from his horse very lightly, and found that the king of Numidia was on foot
ready for to defend himself, and crying out: Knights, succor, succor, or
else I am but dead. At the which noise all the other five knights looked about,
and when they saw the king in the power of that valiant knight, they would
have rescued him, but the light of all knighthoode which was the father and the
son, did disturb them, and put themselves before them, and would not suffer
them to give any such aid, but did there great wonders, striking on every
side, in such sort, that now one and then the other they made them to recoile
back. The strong and furious Eleno did but little harm with his swoorde,
neither made he any great resistaunce, the Giant with as little have as might
be went to help the Numidian king, and with a reasonable pace he went toward
the place whereas the king was, (but for that reason would not consent that
such as he is should be helped) with the have that he made, his horse
stumbled, in such sort, that horse and master fell to the ground, of the which
he was very sore hurt and bruised, as it appeared by his slow rising up again.
The valiant Sardenian with great policy procured to bring to an end his
desire, before that any did come to disturb him, and being lighted of his
horse he made have to the King and said: Thou traitor, it shall little profit
or pleasure thee to call for help, for yt in my hands thou shall leave this thy
traitorous soul, who does deserve to suffer all the evils that may be, and
therewith he stroke him such a blow upon his healme, and with so great
fury, that he made him in spite of his heart to kneel with both his knees
upon the earth. So when the Sardenian perceived him to be in this case, with
great valiantness he straight ways laid hold of his healme with his left
hand, and pulled it clean from his head, and with his right hand he smote
him such a blow upon the head, that he parted it in two pieces, and
immediately he fell down dead to the ground, and looking about to see whether
his horse were gone or no, he found that he was nigh at hand. Then he took
the dead king and made him fast unto the stiroppes of the Saddle, and with a
trice he leapt upon his horse, and so without any help of his stiroppes, he
made his horse to run, and so drew the king after him throughout all the
field. The Gyaunt would have succored him, but all was in vain. In this
sort went Tefereo drawing the king after him before all the knights that were
there present and said: Knights, what do you mean to be so still? Why do
you not uphold and defend this traiterous king, in whose strength was all his
confidence? Behold now where he has received the payment, that such evil
works as his deserved, and therewith he rode round about the field as he did
before. The Emperor when he saw that this fact was ended, would that his
cousin Don Eleno, and the Prince his son should leave their battle, which
was between them begun a new, and they were giving one another terrible
blows, but not with such great fury, for that they did know the one the
other, otherwise it would have gone ill on both parts. The Emperor put
himself between them and said.

Oh Knights, cease your battle and hearken unto my words. Eleno which was
still kindled in wrath, had no respect unto those words, neither would he
part, but like a man distraught from himself, he doubled such a blow upon
the visour of the Emperor, that he made him loose the sight of his eyes. The
Emperor who was very angry and not a little grieved, at the small regard
that he had of his words, would presently have revenged the blow, but that
he was disturbed by the Gyaunt, who pulling off his healme went toward the
place whereas these three worthy warriors were, and with a heavy and
troubled voice he said.

Hear me O noble Emperor and you worthy knights, cease this your
controversy and stay your vnweakened arms, till such time as I have uttered
that which I will say. Then the Emperor with his accustomed meekness said.
Noble King, what is it that thou can demand of me, that I would not
willingly accomplish? To whom he answered. Well, seeing it is so my Lord, I
do desire you to return unto your Tent, and take your ease, and to leave off
this, and such like controversies: for that the cause thereof, my cousin and
brothers son, has taken away from between you. And when he had said these
and such like words, he returned unto his companions, and persuaded them
altogether to return unto the City, to the which they all consented,
although it was clean contrary unto the will of Don Eleno. So when they were
entered into the City, they found that all the people and burgesses thereof
were in great lamentation for the loss of their king and Lord, and the more,
for that his death was so shameful and odious. But they rested not till they
came to the Kings Pallayce, whereas they were received, and were unarmed, and
commanded the dinner to be made ready, whereat they were meruailouslye
served. And when that dinner and all was ended, the valiant Giaunt began to
speak in this manner.

Worthy Princes, and my Lords and friends, you do well know, and here you
have seen, how that all our travail which we have had for to defend this
king, has been greatly against our honors, and that neither our threatenings
nor words were sufficient for to disturb the will of the Emperor herein: for
that he knew that his quarrel was very certain and just, which was the
occasion, that the punishment of this fact in all things has been favorable
according unto his desire. And for the better verefieng of the same, at that
present time you saw come in place, his worthy son, accompanied with my
brothers son my cousin, that with their aid he should conclude to put in
execution his just and true desired reuengement: which has been a great
reproach and ignomy unto us all, neither was there in any of us so much force or
st^ength to withstand or disturb him: but after the king being slain, as you
all did see, they tied him to the stirrops, and dragged him through all the
field. So that now you ^hal understand, the king being dead our oat^ is free,
and we at liberty, neither stand we bound unto any other thing. And that
which we ought at this present to be agreeued at, is, for that we are out of
the grace and favor of our Lord the Emperor. Therefore one of us being his
brothers son, another his son in law, and another his brother in law, and
all the rest his dear and entire friends, for that we do well know that he
was not the occasion of this our fond offense. Let us now acknowledge our
fault, and procure to enter again into his favor and friendship, and go
altogether and discharge our selves, for that it is n^ shame unto us, to ask
pardon for our faults and offenses. Here have I declared unto you my opinion
and my will: and I promise you I am determined to do this, so that euery^ one
may herein do, as best shall please him, and as he shall see occasion. The
first that answered hereunto, was the va^^ant Tartarian, and said.

Excellent king, your counsayl^ herein does like me very well, and we ought
not to take any other counsel, but this only which thou have given us: for
that we see playnelye* that it has pleased God to punish us, for that we would
defend and maintain such evil and naughtiness, and without any farther
counsel we did subject our selves by our oaths: therefore I do determine my
self to follow thy pretended intention. So likewise this counsel seemed good
unto the rest of the Knights and Princes* repenting themselves of all that had
been past. Don Eleno, who was almost confounded for the controversy that was
betwixt him and his Cousin, with an altered and angrye voice, he presently
replied.

I do not deny, but that this which has happened, has been to our infamy as
much as may be, by the which it is known yt we have not maintained ye truth.
But for all that I will not give unto the Emperor nor unto ye rest so much
glory, but let them make an end to triumph over our baseness: for as for my
part, I will first die, and be cut all to pieces* then to go and yeeldo my
self unto them, nor to any person in the whole world. Let every one do as he
thinks best, for that the Dacian Prince will not let to be the same, which
his fortune has ordained, and therewith he arose up from the table, and made
as though he went unto his chamber, but he did not: for incontinent he called a
Lackey of his, and armed himself, and commanded him very secretly to carry
his horse out of the City, and to tarry for him there, and the lackey did as
the prince had commanded him. So when he was out of the City, he leaped upon
his horse, and carried in no place till he came unto the waters side, and by
chance he came unto the place whereas the bark was, that brought his cousin
thither, into which he entered, and his lackey put in his horse. He was no
sooner in, when that with great swiftness the bark began to make sail,
whereas we will leave him till time do serve.

Now I will return unto the Princes, who after many reasonings, determined to
go forthwith unto the Emperors tent, and went unto the chamber of Don Eleno*
to persuade him to do the like, but when they came there, they neither found
him nor his armor, for the which they were very sad and sorry, imagining
straight way what he had done. And seeing that it was labor lost to go and
seek him, they themselves determined to depart without him. And when they
came unto the scowtes of the host, it was asked them what they fought, and what
they would have? The Giaunt said unto them: Friends, go unto the Emperor, and
tell him that here are the Knights with whom he had all his late contention,
that are very desirous to speak with him. So the scoutes sent a messenger
straight way unto the Emperor. And when he had told it unto him, he commanded
that they should presently let them pass.

When the Emperor understood that they drew nigh unto the Tente, with his
mighty courage, and with his accustomed nobleness, he went out to meet
them, with his royal arms spredde abroad, and so by one and one he lovingly
embraced them all, and also desired them, that there might be no communication
of that which had past, for that it would be the occasion to disturb their
joy and mirth which they ought to use together meeting by adventure together
in strange Countries, so he cast his e^e aside to see where his cousin the
Prince Eleno was, but when he could not see him, he asked for him, and it was
told him all that had passed, and the dolorous end of Lidia, for y^ which they
were very sorrowful, but especially the knight of the Sun, for that he
loved him very much, and if the Emperor his Father had not disturbed him, he
would have gone to have sought him. Likewise the great joy and contentment
which the Giant received in seeing his cous^n Tefereo, was no less then
Tefereos to see his uncle, so that the delight of all of them apparently
appeared. In this sort they passed away the time till it was night without
feeling any pain of their passed travail. The next day in the morning the
king of Cimarra did arise, meruailouslye richlye apparelled, with roabes of
cloth of gold, and went unto the knights, giving them to understand that he
was more contented and in quiet then any other king, in that he was revenged
in such sort as you have heard. This good king never ceased in giving thanks
unto the Emperor for the great courtesy which he received at his hands, and
there they gave order that all the whole camp should return unto their own
country, for that which they came for was concluded, and that their departure
should be in such sort, yt the people should not do any harm, yt which was
straight way accomplished, and they appointed for king over that country a
valiant knight, of whom we will entreat in the third part of this history. So
all the people of the king of Cimarra without giving any occasion of anger or
harm, by the way which they went, came unto the place whereas they left all
their fleet of ships, and there they embarked themselves, and committed their
Sails unto the wind, which they found favorable and prosperous, and brought
them quickly unto Cimarra, whereas the king did detain them fifteen days,
although they were unwilling. At the end whereof they determined to depart
their way toward Grecia, and commanded to freight a very fair ship: so taking
their leave, and shipping themselves, they had a pleasant and peaceable wind,
which brought them unto the haven Pireo in Grecia, whereas they went all a
shore: and all of them took horse saving the great Gyaunt, who travailed on
foot, so they took their way toward Constantinople. And when they came
within two miles of it, nigh unto a great house of pleasure, whereas the
Empress was at that time. In the midst of the way, they saw two knights,
which were in a very great and well foughten battle. Whereas we will leave
them, for to tell you what the Morisco, King of Mauritania did, in the place
whereas we left him.

How that the two Empresses went for to recreate themselves unto a house of
pleasure, and what happened unto them in that journey. And how the King of
Mauritania found them in their pastimes, and knowing who they were, he would
have laid hold upon the Empres Briana. Cap. 27.
BEfore in the history, if you do remember, the fierce Moore Brufaldoro came
unto the place whereas a company of Ladies and damsells were, whereas he
stayed to look and behold them: and with them were sitting knights of a good
disposition, and well proportioned. At which time as we began to entreat of
them, I did not tell you who they were: but now you shall understand, that they
were the two Empresses of Constantinople and Trapisond, who were come unto that
house of pleasure for to recreate themselves, which was very nigh unto a fair
village. And the occasion of this their going forth, was the great esteemed
Queen of Lira, (of whom till now our history has made no mention, nor of her
surpassing excellencies, but has referred them till time did serve) She
being many times with the Empress Claridiana, heard her teil of some feats
of knighthoode that had passed by her, the which the Queen with great
contentment gave ear unto, imagining within her self to be of as good
disposition, and have as much strength as she, yea, and rather more: and
knowing that her strength was much, she purposed very secretlye to prove her
self, and taking this place (whether as they went to recreate themselves) to
be very fit for to perform her will, with all secrecy in the world, she
commanded that her armor (which Lirgandeo had presented unto her) should be
carried thither, which was fulfilled and done by the damosells, for that they
all had a great delight to pleasure and serve her, she was of them so
well-beloved, and her excellent virtues deserved no less. So when they were come
unto the house of pleasure, she went forth to recreate her self with two
Ladies toward a fountain somewhat out of the way, whereas the Empres and her
Ladies were set down. And for that the Empress Claridiana did understand,
(whether by her own imagination, or that Lirgandeo had advised her) that in
such place commonly does fall out some adventures, she commanded to give unto
her, her armor, which she caused to be brought unto that house: and whilst
she was arming, came the Moore Brufaldoro, thither: who seeing so fair a
company, had a great desire to know who they were, and coming unto a damsel
which was thereby, speaking with great courtesy, he said. Damsel let me
obtain. I pray you, so much favor at your hands, that you will tell me who
they be that are in this fair company. This damsel seeing that with so great
courtesy and good manners he did request her, and being a knight of so good
disposition, she said. Sir knight, they be the Empress of Grecia and her
Ladies, which are come to this place to recreate themselves: and have brought
hither for their sauegard these well proportioned knights. When the Moore
understood that there was the Empress of Grecia, there entered straight way
many things in his imagination, and many thoughts troubled his mind, till such
time, as he dermined to do that, which I will tell you.

So with a determined purpose he came unto the place where as the Empress was:
and without saying any word, he took her vy the arm, and with great
strength lift her up, till he had her on his saddle bow before him, and
tourning his horse about he took his way toward that place, from whence he
came, with purpose to imbarke himself again, in that ship in which he came
thither, and so to carry her away: but the noise and shrikes of the Ladies and
Damosells were so pitiful and loud, that there came unto them the knights
that were dispersed abroad in the forest and other places. And when they came,
and saw all that had passed, they altogether followed the Moore, so fast as
their horse could run: and in a short time they came for to take away his
booty, so that whether he would or not, he was driven to let her go, for to
defend himself from ye blows which the knights laid on him, who on the one
side and on the other, began to strike fiercely at him: but he made no more
reckoning of them, then the huge and mighty Rock does of the troublesome
waves of the seas, beating against it continually. Even so were the blows
which the Greek knights stroke upon the Pagan, who seeing himself hindered of
his purpose, drew out his sword, and stroke one of those knights such a blow
upon the shoulder, that he cut him down to the girdle, so that he fell down
dead to the ground: and not content heerewith, but began so to bestur himself,
that in a small time, he separated them all, some slain and some very sore
hurt and wounded. In this ^ime, that these knights were in their battle, the
Empress Claridiano was armed, and set upon a mighty strong horse, and came
with great ire, and said. Oh infernal Pagan, what devil was that, which made
thee so bold with those vile and wicked hands to come and take hold of the
Empress: and in saying these words, she drew out her sword, and stroke him
such a blow upon the healme, that she made him boow his head unto his breast:
but straight ways the Pagan came to himself, and firming his feet in his
stirroppes he made her answer, with a blow no less furious then that that
he had received. So there began one of the best foughten battles that ever
was between two Knights. The Empress when she saw her self clear out of
the hands of the Moore, got on the one side, and sat down upon the green
herbs and did behold the battle. All the Ladies and Damosells when they
saw her at liberty, ran unto the place whereas she was, and in small time
they had compassed her with a mild lamentation. At the same time out of the
thickest of the Forest came forth a Knight very well armed, with green
armor, all to be spotted with Lyllyes; and his sheelde of the same manner, but
in the midst thereof was painted a hand, which seemed to be in a lake of
water, holding in it a Lilly flower. And as he saw that furious battle, he
went unto one of the Ladies, and with a gracious courtesy he demanded the
occasion thereof. The effect thereof she told, and declared unto him which was
the knight that was in the Empress defense. At this time the battle was so
kindeled, that with the furious blows that were given, it had been sufficient
to have cut a rock in pieces. This strong Empress was so wrathful, that her
battle was more governed with ire then by policy, and with the great
choler that she had, she stroke the Pagan so terrible a blow, that he fell
down upon his horse neck, without any remembrance, and with the sound of
that terrible blow the horse was somewhat scarred, in such sort, that he carried
his master a while about the field. The Empres following him with her light
horse, thinking that she had made an end of the battle, when that in the
midst of her course, the Moore came to himself again, and with madness, he
fomed at the mouth, and beginning to use his accustomed cursings against
Mahomet. And recovering his sword, taking it fast in both his hands, he went
toward the Empress Claridiana, threatening her with a furious blow.

The Empress who saw the blow coming, she lift up her sheelde to receive
it therewith, the blow fell so terrible thereon, that it parted it in two
pieces, and lighted on her healm^ in such great force and fury, that it made
her to fall backwards upon the crouper of her horse without any feeling,
voyding much blood out of her visour, with which blow the horse was scarred,
and ran round about the field, the which when the Pagan saw, he followed
after the Empress, as the hawk, when you have taken of her hood, discovering
the Heron, with great fury flies at her: even so went this Moore saying. Now
will I see Empress, whether all the strength of this knight be sufficient for
to hinder me, that I carry thee not into a place, where Mahomet shall not be
able to deliver thee, nor take thee out of my hands.

Then the gentle Knight of the Lillyes, did put himself before the Empress,
and said. Stand thou proud Pagan, for first before thou do that which thou
think to do, it stands thee in hand to look to thy self, and in saying
these words, he drew out his sword, and stroke him such an overthwart blow
upon the visour of his healme, that he was ready to fall down on the other
side, and with the strength thereof, it deprived him of his sight, and after
that he stroke another blow on the other side, that the Moore was not able to
make any defense, but that he fell down upon his horse head. The Moore being
kindeled with great madness, to see two such mighty blows given him, and he
not able to make any defense. when he was come to himself, he went against his
adversary with his sword fast in both his hands, who was in the same sort
tarrying for him: and they struck both together such terrible blows, that both
of them were constrained to embrace their horse necks for not falling: but
setteling themselves again, they recovered their swords, and pressed the one
against the other, as commonly the wild Bulls do in their fight, with the
like ire these two joined together, making one of the most perilous battles
in the world, striking one another whereas they might do most harm.

It was so much without pity, and with so furious wrath, as though it had
been two Lions, and giving such notable blows, and battering of the copper and
iron with such great noise, that it did not only glowe in the ears of those
Ladies and the rest that were looking on, but the mountains thereabout were
moved with compassion and pity, to see their great cruelty one toward
another. At this time the Empress Claridiana was come to her self, and when
she remembered the great peril in the which she was, she called unto God for his
help, and tourning about her light horse with so great swiftness, that
wheresoever he did put his foot, there was no sign seen, she came unto the
place whereas the battle was. The Knight with the golden Lyllyes with a high
voice said. Most mightle and Imperial Lady, take you the Empress and carry
her away, and leave her in safety, and let me alone to punish this
discourteous Knight.

Then the Empress and all her Ladies did call her and said. Ualyaunt and
worthy Lady, provide to set us at liberty, where we may be out of danger,
that you may return in time to help this Knight that has done us so much
good. The Empres consented heereto at their requests, and so taking their
palfrayes, they went with great have unto the Village. But when the Pagan did
understand, that it was a woman, which had brought him into so great
extremity, with a great noise he said. Oh vile Mahomet, false, and of a base
kind: for thou, to do me more evil and shame, have ca^sed me to enter into
battle with a woman, who has brought me into this necessity. Oh traitor,
and fa^sifier of thy faith, come down from the Cottage whereas thou art, and I
will give thee to understand, that thou thy self with all thy might shall not
be able so much to anger me, in that thou have so despitefollye for my
dishonor and shame, put me in battle before a woman. The gentle knight with
the Lillyes to those words said.

Hold thy peace Pagan and be still, and speak not so proudly, whereas in
resp^ct thereof thou shall not be feared: for here I do certify thee, that
the Empress Claridiana has brought into subjection many better then thou art,
and made them to stoop. And for that thou shall understand how little thou art
esteemed in Greece, and how much more thou may complain thy unhappiness,
know that I am likewise a woman as she is, and am called Archisilora Queen of
Lira, and with the strength of my arms, I hope to cut off this wretched head
from thy accursed shoulders. And it was very true which was spoken, for when
she went away from the company of the Ladies, she went to arm her self, with
purpose to demand battle of the Empress Claridiana, but when she came
forth, she found them as you have already heard.

The Pagan could be no more angry and wrathful then he was, and without
speaking any word, he turned and stroke very strongly at the Queen, who with
no less fury defended her self, and returned his blows with both her hands,
that it made a marvelous noise. At this present time approached the two lights
of all knighthood, the Emperor of Grecia and his son, and with them the
Giaunt and the rest of the Princes that came with them. You shall understand
that these were the two knights, that in the high way they found in cruel
battle, and meruailing very much at the power that was in the two warriors,
they stayed to behold them, not knowing who they were. The Knight of the Sun
who had his eyes more fixed on them then the rest, did know the Pagan, as one
which had first proved his furious force, and turning unto ye Emperor his
father he told him all that which had happened unto him in the fierce battle
which he had fought before with him in France.

Then they esteemed much the knight with the Lilies, to see how well and how
valiauntly he did behave himself, not only in this subtle defense, which
against his adversary he made, but also his policy he made in offending his
enemy. So the knight of the Sun with the great desire that he had to
revenge himself on the Pagan, moved his horse toward him. At which time
there came forth of the village a Knight with white armor, all full of
Garlands of gold, made by subtle art. Likewise his sheelde was white, and
there was painted on it an Imperial head, which showed as though it had been
cut off with a cruel knife, the throat all so be rayed with blood, very
artificially wrought, and when he saw the battle, he put himself to
behold them, at such time as the valiant Greek approached unto the two
knights that were in battle for to speak unto them, and he said: Worthy
knight with the Lyllyes, for courtesies sake (if this battle be of small
importance) that thou would let me alone with this Pagan, for that I have a
just quarrel against him. This excellent Lady looking upon the knight of the
Sun as one which had never seen him, meruailing much at his fair
disposition, and replied, saying: I would be very glad sir Knight, for your
great courtesy and gentle demeanor, to leave to you the battle, if the
occasion were not of so great weight. Therefore I do desire you that you
would stand aside, for if my success fall out unfortunately, there will time
enough remain, for to execute your anger. The Moore did well understand the
demand of the Knight of the Sun, and knew him very well to be the same
that gave him the order of Knighthood, and when he saw him, he roared like a
furious Lion, saying: Oh vile and base Knight, to whom Mahomet has given more
power and strength then he has himself, come, come, and bring with thee in
company all these that be there with thee, for of all you together I do
esteem nothing at all, and in saying these words, he pressed unto the Knight
of the Sun, very fiercely and with great courage the knight of the Sun
met him in the way, and put himself before the Queen, but this excellent
Lady with great lightness returned and did recover her standing, and said
unto him.

Knight, be not so far out of measure, to give ease and help unto them that
give thee no thanks for it. But the Prince who was then burning with wrath,
retour^ed again by the left side to put himself before her, and gave the
