himself thereof, fell down flat on the ground, for that he had no time to
make any other defense. But that terrible blow was not so soon passed over
him, but straight ways he was on his feet, at such time as the furious beast
came toward him. Here the Prince having a great confidence in his own
strength, did so high and valiant prowess, that you may put in oblivion, all
the valiantnes that ever was done by his predecessors, and put this in
perpetual memory. For that he threw his sword out of his hand, and went unto
this monster, and embraced himself with her, and did so quease her betwixt his
mighty arms, with so much strength yt the furious beast could not profit her
self of her sharp claws, but only with her wings, she beat him on every side,
this valiant warrior would never let her loose, but still remained holding her
fast between his arms, continuing this perilous wrestling, being all imbrued
with her beastiall blood y^ issued out of the wound, which was a great help
unto him against ye furious fiend, which was the occasion yt she lost a great
part of her strength. Long time endured this great and dangerous wrestling,
and that infernal beast fast unto the noble and valiant breast of the Greek
Prince, till such time as he plainly perceived yt this monster begane to wax
faint and to loose her strength: likewise it could not be otherwise but yt the
prince waxed somewhat weary, notwithstanding he did animate himself seeing ye
great weakness of ye Serpent, which was by reason of the great quantity of
blood which came from her wound, and having opportunity he took his sword
wherewith he thrust her into the heart with so great strength yt he cloue it in
two pieces, and so this infernal monster fell down dead to the ground, and
carried the Prince with her, for that they were still fast together, and by
reason that she lacked her strength to make her defense he quickly cleared
himself out of her claws, and recovered his sword, and when he saw certainly
that he was clear from ye cruel monster, he kneeled down and gave great
thanks unto his Gods, the poison was great which this monster threw out for to
infect the knight, but by reason of the great virtue which was in the armor
that Galtenor gave him, there was nothing yt could hurt him, although he
remained very weary and unquiet, and was constrained to sit and cool and
refresh himself by a well which was full of water there hard by, whereas ye
furious beast came forth, and when he found himself somewhat refreshed he
looked about him and saw a pair of stairs, whereat he determined to go up: he
had not ascended many steps, but at the clift of a door which he found, he saw
sitting at a great table many people eating and drinking, and at the upper end
there sat the gyantesse, and next unto her by her side a mighty great and
furious Giant, such a one as he had never seen the like, and harkening what
they did say, he heard yt the giantesse said: Now has our revenger his dinner
between his claws, for that he is so quiet, although he has been a great
while in making of it ready, then ye giant asked and said: Was there any of you
which saw what armor this knight brought and what recognices he had, then one
which was there eating said: I did see what recognices he had, then the old
magical witch said unto her son, now that you certainly know he is dead, I
will tell you who it was: You shall understand yt it was the knight that slew my
two sons and thy brothers. The giant when he heard this, stroke with his hand
a great blow upon the table, saying: Oh Gods, and wherefore did you not tell me
thereof before, that I with my own hands might have taken the reuengment,
cursed be thine enchantments, for yt they are the occasion yt the mighty force
of my arms do loose the glory yt they do deserve. All this which was spoken
the knight heard, and by their reasons he knew that they were all of the
lineall desent of those giants which he slew, for to set at liberty ye
Princess of the valley, and hearing himself so vilely spoken of he could not
endure to stand there long, for his cholar did so overcome him, yt he could not
longer refrain, but set his shulder unto the door with so terrible strength,
yt he threw it down to the ground, at which fall it made a terrible noise,
which caused al them that were there to be greatly amazed, but yet their wonder
was much more to see that the knight was at liberty and clear from that ugly
beast, who they thought had been dead and devoured by her, but when they saw
him they all procured to hide themselves and to run away, so that the Giant
remained all alone in that place, and rising up from the board, stretching
himself on his feet, he said: O my Gods I do give thanks for y^ you have
delivered this vile knight from ye power of yt furious beast, that I with my
hands may take reuengment of him. And in saying these words he drew out a
mighty sword which he had hanging at his side, and went toward the prince
striking at him a terrible blow, from yt which this Greek did clear himself
with his accustomed lightness, and being past yt blow he said: Giant, go and
arm thy self, and here I will tarry for thee, by which means thou may
defend thy self, and make thy reuengement as thy heart desires, and do not
thou think that I will glory in the abating of thy courage, but with the
great valor the which my high mind does demand. The Giant when he saw
himself derided and that the knight made little account of him, was with the
great anger which he received almost beside himself, and said: Oh vile and
miserable creature, is it possible that the Gods will do me so great outrage,
as to consent that I shall take armor against thee, and that thou have so much
force, as to drive me unto that necessity. And in saying these words, he lift
up again his broad and mighty sword against the prince, who likewise cleared
himself of that blow as he did of the first. Then the Prince said unto him:
Thou deformed beast without any humane reason, do not procure by thy great
pride to spot or stain the nobility of my person, to cause me to strike thee,
without having any armor, to make thy defense. The Giant made little account
of ye counsel he gave him, but rather assalted him with more terrible blows.
But all that ever he did was in vain, for that the Prince with great
experience and lightness cleared himself from them, and tarried ye time, that
he might have opportunity to close with him, for to show him the fruits of
his fists, for at that time he had not drawn his sword. A good while they were
in this contention, till such time as those Knights which ran away (which was
to the number of ten) had time to arm themselves, and to return again into
that place whereas they were eating, who came all in a readiness with their
swords in their hands. When the Prince saw the great peril which was toward
him, he was constrained to draw out his sword for to make his defense against
that wicked company. The old Witch called with a mighty voice unto her son,
that he should enter in and arm himself, for that she suspected as a Divine,
what should happen. (O cursed heart, that is so great a friend unto cruel
reuengment: how do thou procure to heap upon thy self such shame and
reproach, seeking without all Justice to do that, which it were better for thee
to have left undone.) Full little did it profit this old Witch her great
crying out, and inchauntments, for that the Giant would not hearken unto her,
but followed his pretense unarmed as he was, against him, who although he had
been armed, his fury would little have profited him, so by reason that ye other
armed Knights did so much trouble him with their blows, it was the occasion
that the Giant did the more molest him, causing him many times with the fury of
their blows to boow his knees to the ground, the which did constrain him to
use all his power against them, striking about him on the one side and on the
other, that in a small time he overthrew five of them dead to the ground, yet
for all that the other five which remained did not let to use all the
extremity they could against the Greek, and likewise that furious Giant whom
the knight would never offer to strike with his cutting sword, but always
waiting opportunity that he might close with him, for to give him one blow
with the pomell thereof, and when time did serve, he would not loose it, but
being very nigh him, he stroke him so mighty a blow with the pomell of his
sword under his ear, that he drove it into his brains, wherewith the Giant
fell dead to ye ground. The other five knights when they saw that terrible
blow, they threw their swords unto the ground, and yielded themselves unto the
courtesy of ye Greek knight. The old Gyantesse when she saw her son dead,
and those knights yielded, with a great fury and terrible shriking she put her
self before the knight and said: O cruel Butcher, the destroyer of my
well-beloved sons, make now an end of her who does more deserve the death then
they, and do not think that thou shall obtain so much victory as to carry
me away with thee alive, and if that with thy cruel hand thou will not make
an end of her that is without all good fortune, I promise thee that I will
procure to give it my self with my own hands. And in saying these words she
went unto the place whereas he son lay dead, and laid hold on his sharp
sword, and with a trice she thrust it into her body, that none that were there
present had any time to withdraw her from doing it, which being done, her
miserable soul was scant out of ye unhappy body when yt all the Castle
began to shake, and with the noise of a terrible thunder clap it vanished
away, in such sort that all those yt were there present remained in the plain
field without any sign or token of castle to be there or any other kind of
buildings, for that you shall understand, that this Castle was made by Art of
inchauntment by that old Witch. Surely it caused great admiration to all them
that remained a live: but much more was the grief of the Ladies which tarried
for ye coming of ye Prince, when they saw yt he tarried so long, and also
afterward when they heard that great noise of thunder, at the breaking up of
that inchaunted Castle. It was no less to be wondered at, to see the huge and
mighty Serpent, and the great giant with his mother, and the five knights that
were slain, understanding that the Prince had made all that destruction. So
the five Knights which yielded themselves, gave the Prince to understand who
the Giants were, and how the old Giantesse had ordained that Castle for to take
reuengement on him, for the death of her two sons. The Greek Prince gave
thanks unto his Gods, for that they had delivered him out of that terrible
snare, and gave the Knights free liberty to depart, and go whether they
would.

Then the Prince and his company returned onwards to their journey, making
great have in their trauaylyng, that they might get out of that great Wood,
before that the night should come upon them, whereby they might get to some
town nigh at hand. And at such time as the glistering Apollo began to hide his
face, and to cover himself, according to his accustomed order, they came unto
a fair Castle, which was a little without the wood, whereas of the Lord
thereof, they were very well received: yet much more royal was their
entertainment, and far greater was his affection toward them, when he knew
of ye destruction of that inchaunted Castle, for that he had felt and known
the inconvenience of that ill neighbor.

How that the king of Nabatea had understanding of the great destruction that
the Greek Prince made in the castle, and how he commanded that the serpent
and the heads of the Giants should be set at the entry of the gate of the
Pallaice for a perpetual memory, and how that the triumph began that was
ordained, and of all that passed in the time of the feasts. Cap. 14.
THE fame of the valiant knight Claridiano, with his accustomed gentillitie was
noised throughout all those Provinces of Nabatea, publishing his heroical
acts and feats of arms, naming him to be the knight of the damsells, and
when he drew nigh unto Nabatea, there did not lack them which gave the king to
understand of all that passed. When the king heard of so mighty and valiant
deeds, and in special of that which was done in the inchaunted castle, and
of the furiousness of the serpent, he commanded straight yt men should be sent
thither, for to bring them unto his presence which straight way was
accomplished, and when the King saw, so great worthiness, he commanded that
forthwith for a perpetual memory of ye knight, they should be hanged at ye
pallaice gate, desirous to know ye knight, and to have him in his court for to
do him honor: but they which had more desire to see him, were ye Duchess of
the valley and her Daughter. Who were at that time come so the Court, and
declared the great prowess of the Prince, and thought long for the day of
the Triumphs, for as then he promised without fail to be at Nabatea, so the
day of the feasts were come, at the fame whereof, resorted thither a great
number of great valor and strength. Amongst whom was the prince of Phoenicia
with a goodly company of noble person, and the Prince of Camogenia with many
and very well proprtioned Knights. Likewise came thither the King of Arabia,
with great majesty, and with no less majesty came the king of Silicia, and
a brother of his, who were both Giants. So likewise came thither the king of
Cappadocia, all these be Provinces that does border the one with the other, and
the most part of these Princes are vassalls unto the Prince of Palestino, all
these Princes came thither for to honor that good king of Nabatea, for that he
was very well esteemed of them all: and as they came to honor the King, so
likewise they came to prove themselves, and to get fame and name, and the
praise that belongs thereunto. It was supposed of all the company the king
of Silicia would have the prowess and praise of all the rest, for that he was
a giant of very big members, although his brother was taken to be more
furious, who determined not to just, for that his brother should get the honor
and praise, but it fell out otherwise, as hereafter you shall understand. So
when the day was come all the Ladies and Damsells put themselves in places for
to behold ye feasts, and every one procured to set out her self with the
greatest bravery yt might be, and the great court full of people which came
thither for to see the feasts and triumphs. What shall I say here of the
daughter of the Duchess of the valley, who was of so great beauty yt she was
noted amongst them all. So the knights began to enter into the place of just,
and he which was the first that entered was the Prince of Camogenia, who was
mounted upon a very fair and well adorned courser, he was armed with black
armor all to be spotted full of Martines, and brought with him fifty
knights all apparelled with the same liuerey, and with great^ majesty he went
round about the place, making obedience unto all the Ladies and Damsells: after
him entered a Pagan knight, who was Lord of Siria, and armed with armor of a
Lions color, accompanied with an hundredth knights, all apparelled in velvet
of the same color, and passed round about the place, showing great courtesy
as the other did, which being done, he saw that the Prince of Camogenia was
tarying to receive him at the just, and straight way they began to sound the
instruments, giving to understand, that they must make themselves ready. These
Knights were nothing unwilling, but spurred their coursers with great fury. The
Prince of Camogenia made his encounter whole, and stroke the Pagan without
missing any point: but the pagan stroke the other in such sort that he heaued
him out of the saddle, and he fell to the ground, wherewith the Pagan Knight
remained with great pride and gladness. In the mean time that these two were
in the Just, there entered in a Knight of Phenicia, who entered in with great
pomp and pride, who when he saw that the Prince of Camogenia was overthrown,
he put himself unto the Just. Little did profit him his great pride and
arrogancy, and outward show to be a strong knight against him of Siria, for
that at the first encounter he overthrew him to the ground: in like sort did he
use other fifteen Knights of diverse Provinces. So straight way entered the
Prince of Phoenicia, who was a marvelous well proportioned knight, armed all
in white armor, wrought with excellent knots of gold, and he brought in his
company an hundred Knights, all apparailed in white satin, and riding about
the place, he showed his obedience unto the King and all the Ladies. Then he
put himself at his standing, for at that time there was not a knight to just
withal. So straight way they sounded the trumpets, at which noise the Knights
moved themselves to the Just with their horses, and made their encounter so
strong, and with so great fury, yt the strong Pagan was cast to the ground,
and the like he did to other six ventrous Knights, which entered into the
place. Straight way entered the brave King of Silicia, who was armed with
glistering armor of very fine steel, and was mounted upon a very mighty and
rich courser, and brought in his company two hundred Knights all apparailed
with rich cloth of gold, accompanied with great music of minstrelles which
was a pleasant noise to be heard, and after that he had made the accustomed
compass and courtesy in the place, he put himself at the Just. So whe^n signs
were made, they spurred their^horses, and made their encounter so strong, that
it was great grief unto him, to put himself upright again, but the prince was
carried over his horse buttocks, and carried the saddle with him betwixt his
legs, which was a great grief unto all them that did see him, for that he
was wel-beloued of them all. This arrogant giant was so encouraged, and so
furyous that in a small time he left not a knight remaining in their saddles on
horseback. And being in this great pride, there was hard a great noise and
russhing, in manner of a tumult in the place. And loking what it should be, they
saw that it was the knight of the Damsells which entered, who was armed with his
rich and strong Armor, all of Purple, full of golden Stars. And before him
came the two Damsells, which always were in his company. The Princes of
Ierosolima, carried his shield, and the Princes of Mesopotamia* his Spear.
Showing by his person the highness of his descent. Who passed by the royal
seat whereas the good King was, in whose company was his son the prince, armed
with very rich armor, also the lord of mount Libano, a very ancient knight
and of great authority. So on the other side was the princes, the daughter of
the King of Nabatea, who was the bryde, a very fair and comely gentlewoman,
and with her the Duchess of the valley and her Daughter. And behind them, was
the Earl of the deep Lake, who was still very weak of the passed battle,
and was richly apparelled with blew cloth of Gold. And as this knight passed
by, the knight arose up and showed him courtesy. The Duchess of the Ualley
could not refrain her self but that with a high voice she said unto the King.
Mighty king, this is the knight in whom the gods has put all their power and
strength, that his valor may be more then theirs. This warlike knight,
although he heard very well what the Duchess had said, passed on, and
descembled as though he had hard nothing. And when he came to the Just, he took
his shylde and his spear, and prepared himself ready to the Just. So straight
ways being in a readiness, they sowned the Trumpets, where at which great
fury, they moved their Coursers, and neither of them missed their blow at their
encounter, but by reason that the Greek had great good will to extol his fame,
he stroke the giant so mighty a blow, that he overthrew him to the ground. So
the prince passed alongest, with great magestie, without any show of disdain.
The people with a great shout said. The great mighty and royal Agilao is
overthrown to the ground, so that his mighty strength has little auailed
him. Then the prince of Fenicia, would prove his adventure with the Greek, but
with great ease he was turned to the ground. So all the rest of ye knights that
were of any estimation, made their Just, but they were all with great ease
overthrown to the ground, in less then the space of two hours. So at such
time as the bright Febus would make an end of his long journey, there apeared
to enter in to the place the brave and mighty Giant, brother unto the king of
Silicia, with a mighty great spear in his hand, whose glystering point of
Steel showed through all the field. He brought with him but one only squire,
which brought with him another spear, and without any care of courtesy due,
he put himself into the place. And ye Squire which brought his other Spear,
went unto Claridiano, and said: Knight, yonder valiant giant does send unto
thee this Spear, and wills thee that thou do procure to do the uttermost
of thy power before that the Sun does set, for that he will do the like: and
likewise he says, that he does not only defy thee in the Just, but also to
mortal battle. To whom Claridiano, said: Friend, go thy ways and tell this
giant yt sent thee, yt I do accept his demand, although it does grieve me
very much, for that without any occasion he makes this defiance in time of
so great joy and pleasure, which is done in the honor of so mighty a king,
but seeing his will is moved with so great pride, tell him yt I am ready to
make my defense, and also ye shortly he shall repent him of this enterprise,
and in saying these words he took the spear of ye squire, and put himself in
ye standing: at ye time he was very nigh ye place where the king was, who
heard ye answer which ye Greek made, for yt which he received great anger,
for yt the Giant in such sort should defy ye Knight without any occasion: but it
was no time as then to speak, but to hold his peace, and prayed unto his Gods
for to take away his great pride and arrogancy. At this time the two warriors
tarryed the sign to be made by the trumpets: which being given, these Knights
moved their coursers, with their spears in their rests, with so great ire and
desire the one to hurt the other, that they both failed in their encounter. The
Giant who was very proud, when he saw that he had erred his blow, he returned
against Claridiano, carrieng his spear upon his shoulder, and coming nigh
him, upon a sudden and with great fury he took it from his shoulder, and
before the Greek could clear him self, he struck him a mighty blow upon the
armor, so that his staff broke by reason of the finenesse of the armor, and
made the good warrior to double his body backwards upon the Horse crupper.
But when he saw the great villainy which the Giaunt used with him, his anger
increased very much, and taking his spear in the same sort, he went toward
the Giant and said. Thou furious and proud beast, what did thou think to
goare me like as thou would do a wild Boar, tarry, and I will make thee
to understand, if I can make my knottie spear to fly in the air, and
therewith he threw his spear at him with so great fury, that he stroke him on
the breast in such sort, that the spear passed through his body, and showed it
self at his back, so that this Giant fell down dead to the ground, and all
that were there present, were very much amazed at the great-strength and force
of this Knight. At this time the Sun had finished his course, having nothing
above the Horizon but his glistering beams, then the Judges of the feasts
commanded with sound of trumpets that the Iusts should cease, and make an end
of the day. So the King descended from the place where he was into the Court
with all his Knights for to receive that good warrior, and desired him that he
would go with them unto his pallaice, to ye which he could not make denial. And
when he should enter into the great gate of the Pallaice, he saw the Serpent,
and the heads of the Giants, and when the King perceived that he did behold
them, he said.

This remembrance (good knight) I commanded to be put here in thy name, for
to be a perpetual memory of thy high and mighty Chivalry. The Prince there
at would not answer making as though he did not esteem it much, for that he
had with himself no pride. And therewith they assendid up into the great hall,
where as they were maruailously well received of the Ladies and damsells. And
leaving Antemisca, and Belia, with the Bryde, and with the Queen her mother in
law, he returned and went with the King, whereas they did entreat him with
great majesty. So he remained eight days in company with the King in his
court, for to take his ease, in which time the most part of the kings, princes
and knights were departed, and the King of Silicia, with the dead body of his
brother. These eight days past this Greek prince did take his leave of the
King, for that ye time to make defense in the quarrel of the Princess draw
on, the which he had great care thereof. It grieved the king very much for his
departure, but seeing that he was constrained thereunto, he would not hinder
him, but offered him very great and rich gifts, but the prince would not
receive any. Likewise he took his leave of the Queen, and of the Duchess and
her daughter, who with great sorrow did solemnise his departure. The King
brought him unto the foot of the stayre, whereas Fidelio was tarying for him,
with a mighty and rich Horse, one of the furious that was to be found in all
the country. He was a Rone coulored, without any kind of mark, and trapped
with very rich trapping of Gold and precious stones of great price. There came
forth of the ^orse mouth two tuskes like unto an Elophant, his nosethrills
were very large and great, his head very little, his breast very broad, well
pitched and so hard, that no sword were it never so sharp, was able to enter in
thereat. So when he came unto the foot of the stayres, without letting foot
in his stirrup, he leaped upon the best Horse that ever was. The horse was
called Zefiro, for his great lightness. When he had taken his leave of all,
they departed, determining ^ot to stay in any place, till they came unto
Ierosolima, and so straight way to Mesopotamia, for yt it was all one way. Then
they followed on their journey, till they had passed all the kingedome of
Nabatea, without any adventure worth the telling. Likewise they passed all the
mount Libano, where as they found many great and fair Cities. Also they
passed over the river Jordan, leaving behind them part of Siria, travailing a
longst by part of the edge of Pallestina, which bordereth upon Arabia. And
passed through Fenicia, without any question or demand asked of them. So they
came unto ye populus river of Eufrates, and travailed a longst ye rivers side,
till such time as they were constrained to go upon a high and mighty
mountain, from whence they might discover Ierosolima. All these countries
aforesaid, they passed and travailed, in little more then two months, and at
that time there lacked little more then two months unto ye time appointed, for
Antemisca to make her defense. In all this journey there chaunsed some
adventures, but for that they were not of any great importance, I let them
pass, and make no mention of them. Although ye fame of his heroycall deeds,
was hard into Grecia. And for yt my author will not seem to be tedious, he does
let pass many, although they are worthy to be hard, and to give good example
unto all those that do wear armor, to make them hardy and courageous in
their deeds.

How the heroycall Greek was taken prisoner, by the dart of Cupide, in
beholding the beauty of a very fair Pastora, and of the great anguish and
grief that he sustained. Cap. 15.
THat adultresse Venus, the key of all liberty, not having forgotten her old
mischife and ill will, which she took upon the mountain Citareo, came to take
counsel of her son Cupide, to determine what order she might use for to
subject and bring under her amorous yoke, the stiff neck of that stout and
untamed Greek. And the better for to forge and to bring to pass to her
content, ye work which she had ordained, she showed her self very friendly and
lovingly unto ye glistering Apollo, for yt at her request he should with more
clerenesse spread abroad his bright beams over the grene feldes, nigh unto the
river Eufrates. Who being moved by the disceitfull words of Venus, did disperse
abroad his burning beams: showing forth marvelous enamelled colors, upon ye
flowred harbes, being filled with ye clear dew, such as seldom has been seen
in the feelde. And the mighty river with mild and quiet running, did pass his
accustomed journey, making a fine noise, with ye delicate breaking of his
stremes. Then this false and crafty Cupide, seeing opportunity, by ye good
disposition of ye place: and being advertised by his disceitful mother, took
his way with his accustomed lightness, unto the river where as ye mighty
Claridiano was refreshing himself under a company of very fair and grene
Mertil trees, with the rest of his company, tarying the coming of the night,
where as with out all fear, they reioysed and sported themselves, ye fair,
peasable and quiet day. And for to be more at his ease, he pulled of his strong
helm, and slacked ye buckles of his armor. And for that the damse^ls might ye
better recreate themselves, he put him self out of ye way, somewhat apart from
them, for yt he was very courteous and honest. And aparting himself, he came
into a place where as he heard the noise of a Flute, which did sound very
swetly: and for that it was very pleasant, and gave him great contentment in ye
hearing, ye better to delight himself, he drew near where as it was, in such
sort, yt he might delight himself of the song and music, without being spyde
of any. He approached so nigh, yt he might well discern who it was that made that
Flute so sweetly to sound. And he saw that it was a sheperd which lay a longst
under a grene willow tree, who being weary in playing on the Flute, laid it
down by him, and took a Rebick and began to play on it with very sweet
harmony, acco^panying it with delicate and amorous songs. At the which the
Prince receued great conte^tment, being attentive, he heard him sing as
follows.

SInce by thy sight, O Pastora so sweet,
My former freedom and my life does fail:
Repay me love, for that it is most meet,
And let not rigor in thy heart prevail.
Behold mine eyes, with floods of tears that flow,
Forced by the grief that from my heart does grow.
Make soft thy heart, and do not him disdain,
That does adore thy beauty so divine:
Pity my plaints, abate my grievous pain,
With scoffs and scorns constrain me not to pine.
Either grant grace, else flatly nay reply,
That I may know if I shall live or dye.
When he had made an end of this song, he let the Rebeck fall out of his hand,
and stretching himself on the grene grass, crossing his hands, he put them to
his mouth as a man full of passions and griefs, and began to say with a weping
voice, O my Pastora, let thy cruelty now suffice thee, it is now time that thou
helpest thy Pastor out of so long and great sorrow. Consider mistress, that
thou do entreat me very evil, for yt thou do well understand yt I am wholly
thine, and not mine own, and as thine own thou may ordain and dispose me. I
am wholly subject unto thy will, whether it be good or ill, what so ever thy
pleasure is, unto either of them I am agreeable, for yt I am wholly thine. The
Prince saw yt with this shepard was an other in his company, who when he saw yt
the other hild his peace, he took an other Rebeke which he had, and with no less
music then ye other, he began to play and sing, as follows, by ye which he
did show to be clear and at liberty of ye pains of love.

That tyrant Love shall never wound my breast,
I will not love, nor yet beloved be:
The lovers life I do in heart detest,
which now in mirth, are straight in misery.
I being free do Cupids customs scorn,
Reject his laws, disdain his wounding dart:
And let who will, be with his passions torn,
He neither can nor shall possess my heart.
This shepherd left off his song and playing all at one time, as one yt made
no reckoning nor esteemed love, but the amorous shepherd gave so terrible a
sigh yt it sounded throughout all the field. Then making a heavy sound, he
said: O happy shepherd, that love has given so much liberty unto, great is
thy good fortune, that thou may freely publish thy liberty and blame my
captivity. Let the Gods understand, and let it be published, that I am brought
unto that estate, that in my songs and sonets I do delight to utter the
sweet conversation that I have with my love. But how much more joy should I
receive, if I could sing as thou do, in seeing my self at liberty. Oh
mighty Jupiter, do not take away this excellent joy, which I do feel in
loving, like wise I do desire thee, that thou would give me strength for to
pass over my pain and grief, and therewith he took again the Rebick, and
soung this song as follows.

EXcept I love I cannot have delight,
It is a care that does to life belong:
For why, I hold that life in great despite,
That has not sower mixed with sweet among.
And though the torments which I feel be strong:
Yet had I rather thus for to remain,
Then laugh, and live, not feling lovers pain.
This Shepard was troubled in his song, and could not proceed any farther, for
that he hard a great rushing and noise amongst the bushes and trees. And loking
who it should be he saw that it was a Pastora, who was apparaled with a white
peticoate of very course cloth. She had her golden hair dyspersed abroad on
her back, behind her ears, and had in her hand a shepherds hook, very well
wrought, with the which she governed a few sheep, that she had the charge of.
Her face seemed so fair as Diana, at such time as her beams has most force.
And when the Shepard saw her, he began a new to make unto her pitiful
lamentations. But for all that the Pastora made no rekoning to give any ear
unto him, nor to his complaints, but rather with a smiling laughter, made of it
as a jest, which caused unto the Shepehard more torment. Then Cupide who was
tarying his time and opportunity, at yt time discharged his golden Arrow, with
great fury, in such sort, that the heart of the Prince, who aforetime was void
and at liberty, was now brought in subjection and made subject unto his laws
and customs. For so sone as he had seen this Pastora, he straight way
remembered the Pastora which ye Princes of Ierosolima had told him of, and also
of yt which he saw in the enchanted Castle, leaning on her breast at the Iron
grate. And remembering himself, he cast his head a side to behold her that was
ye occasion of his new harm, but for yt she was passed along with her sheep,
he could not see her. Then he began to complain against his unhappy fortune,
saying, Ah heavy heart, that in the time yt thou were a knight and at liberty,
thou did subdue and had power to overcome so many strong warriors: where
is now thy strength become, wherewith thou did overcome the^. Art not thou he
who did overcome those two mighty giants in Trapobana? Art not thou he which
with thy fury did abate ye strength and courage of ye mighty Geredion? what is
become of thy potensie, wherewith thou did bring down ye pride of ye two
Tartaros? what is become of the fury where with thy fystes thou slewest ye great
giant of the mountains Nabatea? where is thy strength wherewith thou did win
thy mighty horse Zefiro. I do see yt it is all yielded unto a poor and simple
Pastora. Oh heart, it does not grieve me, for yt thou art brought in subjection,
but only for yt thou art at ye will and power of a Pastora. It is a sign yt my
lignage is not of such valor and estimation, as I was persuaded by my friend
Galtenor. But what do I say, do I find fault in the desert of my Pastora. And
although I were of ye most highest lynage in the world, yet that fair face is
more then any human creature does deserve. And in saying these words, he fell
in a sownd to the ground. And for so much as he was absent and tarried a long
time, and ye ladies saw he came not, they went out to seek him, and found him
in ye sort as I have told you, which caused great disturbance unto them.
Notwithstanding in the best manner they could, with bowing of his finger, and
other diligences, they brought him again to his remembrance, but not in so
perfect sort, that he knew who was with him in presence. And therewith he gave a
grievous sigh, and said: Oh merciful Jupiter, show upon me thy power, and do not
permit that Cupide, may have so much might against this sorrowful knight. And
therewith a new he fell down in a sownd, as at the first. Both the princes were
greatly amassed, not knowing what it should be, which has caused so much
alteration. And therewith Fidelio ran unto the river for water, wherewith they
all to be bathed his face, that he came again to himself. The Ladies musing
between themselves, from whence should proceed this his grief. Straight way
they suspected yt he had seen that fair Pastora, which a little before they
saw pass amongst those grene trees. Antemisca who had more care of the princes
grief then the other, when she saw him somewhat come to himself, she said:
What is this worthy knight, is it now time to leave me afflicted, the time
being so nigh at hand to make my defense, and almost at ye gates of the city,
pull up your heart, and let not your valiant courage at this time faint. The
knight when he perceued yt the ladies were there, he procured to raise up his
body, and to sit down, for yt before he was laid all a long. And dissembling
in ye best wise he could, he said. I do not know what should be ye occasion of
a maruailous great grief which stroke me to the heart, yt without any power to
make resistance, it overthrew me to ye ground, in such sort as you found me. I
do well believe, said Antemisca, yt the occasion of this grief is in ye heart, and
ye eyes are in most fault. For if thou had not seen the fair Pastora, thy
heart should not have felt ye passed pain. To this Claridiano answered nothing
at all, seeing yt they understood ye occasion of his grief. But he made have to
make all things in a redines to go onwards on their journey, and being all on
horsback they hasted toward Ierosolima, where they were received with great
triumph, meet for such worthy Princes. The old king and Queen gave great
thanks unto their gods for ye return of their lost daughter. Claridiano
remained there in ye city of Ierosolima, six days, greatly against his will.
For that the new wound would not suffer him to take any rest, which caused him
to take his leave of the king and his daughter, and departed, and took the way
toward Mesopotamia, with great desire to be there. So travailing, they left
behind them the City of Damasco, and passed by the one side of Armenia the
great, and so entered into the great plain of Mesopotamia, and from thence
without taking any rest, they came within ten miles of the city of Mesos. From
which place they sent the old Squyre, which was with them, to give the king to
understand of the coming of the Princes, who with great care travailed in such
sort, that he entered into the pallas, at such time as the king was accompanied
with all his knights, not with little sorrow for the absence of his daughter,
for that the time appointed for her defense, drew on. On his one side was the
prince of Palestina, who was as merry and glad, as the King heavy and
sorrowful. But when Libernio entered into the great hall, the king knew him to
be a man of great estimation in his kingedome. And having no power to discemble
his great joy, in seeing him, he forgot his royal authority, and rose up
against him, and said: Ah my friend where have thou left my daughter
Antemisca, tell me quickly, as thou would that the Gods should favor
thee. Then Libernio with a cherefull countenance said, mighty King and
Lord* thy daughter the Princes is very well, although very weary of (...) long
and troublesome journey, and misfortunes which has happened, but yet now with
great delight, for that she does bring with her a knight for to defend her
honor. And if it be so that your highness does accept thereof, and give them
lisence, he will come hither, and defend her right. The prince of Palestina
when he hard that which was spoken, with great laughter, although not very well
content, said. And who is he that is so simple and foole-hardie, to come, and
gaine-saye my fury, the truth being on my side. Libernio said, it is he that
will make thee to acknowledge thy falsehod, and will make thee forget thy fury
and mighty strength, by using of his valiant prowes. Whereat Brandemoran was
so full of wrath, and his eyes sparkling like fire, he said: If it were not
for that I am before the royal presence of the King, I would give thee to
understand, yt thy gray hairs had not spoke with ye discretion, which thou
ought to have. Then the King said, prince pacify your courage, and be
quiet, and thou Libernio return, and tell them that they may come when their
pleasure is. And for the right of my daughter, (if she have any) he shall have
safe conduct to come and make her defense. And if it be so that they have need
of any thing, speak that they may have all furnished that is requisite. Go thy
ways and tarry not, for that I have great desire to see either my shame or
honor. For I am in such a stay, to se my self so dishonored, that I think it
better that I were dead. Ah what a goodly thing is it for a man to dye when he
is in so great troubles. So Libernio put in order his departure out of hand,
leaving the king somewhat content, and almost without suspection of any evil,
seeing that his daughter was returned to defend her right. Libernio when he had
got mourning apparel for the Princes, departed to the place whereas he left
them, declaring unto her all that her father had said, and what passed in his
presence. So therewith they procured and made have, to finishe their journey.
And they made so much have, that before it was night they came within two miles
of the city where as they rested all that night, with great desire that the
morning were come. So very early in the morning at the break of the day, they
put them selves on horseback, and went forwards on their journey. So that one
hour after the Sun had stretched forth his golden beams upon the moist
earth and fragrant flowers, this Greek knight and the Princes entered into the
city of Mesos, not resting in any place, til they came unto the kings
pallaice, whereas they alighted and went up into the great hall. Claridiano led
Antemisca by the hand, his Helm fast upon his head, and his purple Shylde on
his shoulder, but the visor of his Helm was up, so that all people might see
his fair and great visage, and all that saw him, did judge him to be of a high
lynage. Then the King was advertised of their coming, and did abide their
coming in the chamber of presence, accompanied with all his nobles and knights
of prowes. And when he saw his daughter to enter all covered with mourning
apparel, his royal highness could not show the great love he had unto his
daughter, but made shows of great sorrow, shedding many tears from his eyes,
which ran down upon his cheeks, and al to be washed his gray hairs. This
faultlesse lady did prostrate her self at her fathers f^^te, but Claridiano
remained a foot, with so great majesty, as though he had known whose son he
was. This painful and weried lady, did ask her fathers hands to kiss them,
but neither the king nor his daughter could speak any word more. They remained
so a great while, til such time as the king constraining his princely courage,
said. I know not what will fall out, for that I see before me, yt which of long
time I have desired, and yet I do not know it to be mine. The lady understood
ye words of her father, gathered stomach unto her self and said: I am
Antemisca, your well-beloved daughter, although at this time I am abhorred, I am
she who unjustly has gone wandering, paying such debts as I never made, for
that I did never let but to be ye lady I ought to be. I am she that by ye
valor of this mighty and worthy warrior, do live, and not by the compassion
that thou have had of thine own proper daughter. And I do thank my Gods, that
they have so much favored me, in giving me his mighty and strong arm, for to
defend my truth, and for to punish that evil, the which that traitor
Brandemoran, has laid and raised upon me. The brave Palestina, who was
present at the words which the Princes said, was so full of pride and ire,
that without any respect unto the kings highness, he said: Oh false
adulteress, wherefore will thou deny yt the prince of Chaldea, had thy
virginity, and that with thy consent. And what knight is he that is so hardy
and has so much courage, to say unto the contrary. The Greek did very much
behold the Palestinia^, perceuing by his words, that to be he that had
procured all this harm against Antemisca. And although his proud words did move
his patience, yet would he not make any outward show, neither answer unto
him, but rather with great severity, he turned unto the King and said: High
and mighty Lord, in this controversy there is no need of disputation,
neither farther rehearsal. But may it please your highness to command, that
the Prince of Chaldea may come in presence, and to know of him, if he be
content, to refer all his right into my hands. The King who (was considering
and beholding his mighty prowess, in the demonstration of his person)
straight ways commanded to be brought thither ye Chaldean, with sufficient
keepers with him, which was straight ways done.

And when he came in presence, the King said unto him: prince Gelerosio, my
daughter has brought hither this knight, for to defend her and thy right, (if
thou have any.) Here would I know of thee, if that thou art content to refer
all thy right and justice into his hands. The prince Gelerosio somewhat heavy,
answered the king and said, Unto the sovereign Gods and unto him, I do
commit all my right although I had rather with ye strength of mine own arms
make my defense: and tourning unto the Greek, he said. And for that gentle
Knight, thou shall be certified that thou defend the truth: Here I do swear
unto thee by the high and mighty Jupiter, that the Prince of Chaldea, did
never commit yt which with great falsehood he is accused. Then Brandemoran did
replye, and said. All that ever thou do say, I will suffer, for that I do
think before the Sun has made an end of his accustomed course, to have
satisfaction. And likewise to punish the pride of this fool, who by
ignorance or rather foolish hardienesse, comes to seek his own death.

This valiant and courageous Greek could no longer suffer his proud and
slanderous speeches, but said unto him: Jupiter has power to give the death
unto whom he pleases, and I do think that which thou do pretend unto
me, will fall upon thy self, for to punish thee for this thy false and
surmised treason which thou most dispightfully have raised, against this noble
Princes, who is guiltless of this crime.

And for that this must be concluded by arms, and not by words, se that thou
do make no tarying, but arm thy self and come forth unto the battle, and
then thou shall see how I will make thee to understand in the field, that I am
none of them of whom thou have hitherto gotten honor. I will not make thee
any answer said Brandemoran, for that I think very quickly to revenge my
self of thee, and to pluck out ye tongue which has been so bold to speak
these words unto me. And therewith he went straight out of the palace, and went
unto his lodging for to arm himself unto the battle. The Greek at his
answer was somewhat yrefull, but retourning unto the king he said, mighty
king and Lord, I do desire your highness that you would command, that your
daughter may be set in a place, where as she may well see the restoring of her
honor. The King said this shall be done with a very good will, without any
tarying. The Greek did take his leave of the King and of the Ladies that were
in the great hall. And went down the stayres where as he left his page and his
horse, and without the help of his stirrup, he leapt into the saddle, and
having his healme on, and his spear in his hand, he commanded his page to
tarry, and not to go with him. So he went straight unto the place appointed for
the battle, with so gentle a grace and good disposition, that all who did
behold him, received great contentment. There was appointed a scaffold for two
Judges, for to Judge the right of this controversy, and did appoint the place
convenient for their battle. They tarried not long, when that B^^ndemoran
entered ye place, accompanied with many knights, at which time the Judges put
themselves on their Scaffold. And being all ready and the people in quiet,
there was commanded a Trompet to be sownded, to give them to understand, that
they must prepare themselves to the battle. At which sound they moved their
cour^^^s, the one against the other, with so great swiftness, (...) yt they
flew in the Air, whereas I will leave (...) time do serve, for that at the
same present, the wind Borias did blow in my ea^e, cons^rayning me to speak
of the mighty deeds of that valiant Rosicleer. You do well remember, that
for to succor his Horse, he leapt into his bark, and was not so soon
therein, but that it sailed and made such way as the arrow which is forced out
of ye bow. And one of the two knights which entered the bark, leapt into the
Sea for fear, and the other remained, and yielded himself unto the mercy of
the Knight, which afterward did serve him for Squire, and very faithfully used
his office, who was called Argolio. Rosicleer went travailing to sea-wards, in
his Barcke, very heavy and sorrowful, for that he was departed from his cousin
so quickly. In this sort they travailed six days, and the seventh they
discovered land very far of, but the swiftness of the Barcke was such, that
in a short time it brought them to the waters side. And being a land, he saw
that it was an Island, and very fragrant, for that toward the Occident, there
appeared but little plain ground, and toward the Orient, a very high and
sharp Mountain. So when the Barcke had fyxed it self a shore, he understood,
that there he must go a land, and taking his horse, with great lightness, he
leapt into the saddle, and Argolio followed him. And they travailed into a
narrow way which led them up unto that crooked Mountain, and followed that way
till they came to the height thereof, whereas they alighted for to refresh
themselves, with that which the squire brought. And for that I have great need
of favor and help, to go forwards with this history, here I do desire the
Muses to grant it unto me, that I may with more courage, declare that which
follows in the other Chapter.

How that Rosicleer found in that Island, the son of Ali^andro, leading a
troublesome life, with his fair and well-beloved wife, who was set at liberty
by Rosicleer. Cap. 16.
AFter the noble Rosicleer had somewhat refre^hed himself, he took his horse,
and by little and little, he began to go up that fragrant hill, till such time
as night came upon them, and for the great darkness thereof, they were
constrained to stay, and not to travail any farther. But in a little plain
place that they found, they alighted, whereas they found a cave, and in it the
manner of a bed, declaring that some body had been there, so there they
remained all ye night, till ye morning. The day being come, they returned to
prosecute their new begun journey, and never rested till such time as they came
to the top of the mountain: from whence they did discover a very great and
delectable plain: and in y^ midst thereof, there was two great an high Pine
trees, toward which place they went. But they had not gone far, where they saw a
pillar, in the which was graven certain letters, which said. The glory of
Fangamadan, upon the subjection of the Prince, son unto the mighty Emperor
of the Scitas, and of the courageous Troyan: Let none be so hardy as to look
upon it, for that for so doing, he shall lose his life. Rosicleer, was in a
great confusion, not understanding what should be meant there-by, but travailing
in ye path forwards, he had sca^t passed ye place, when yt he hard a terrible
and fearful shryke of a beast, such, that his horse was scared, and began to
struggle in such sort, yt he was constrained to return again and to light on
foot, and gave him unto Argolio, and the knight did prosecute his way on foot.
Within a small while after, he heard yt they turned and gave such an other
shrike, yt it made him for to stay. And as you do see ye fearful Heart, when he
does hear the noise of the hunters, does hold up his head, devising on every
side to hear from which part the noise should come: even so did this knight,
but he could not devise nor see any creature, but went forwards on his way in
the same path, till he came unto a little mountain, whereas he found an other
pillar, such a one as the same before, in the which was written a title with
these words. He who does find himself of so great courage and strength, and
does procure to pass forwards, for to deliver the worthy Meridian, and the
mighty Troyan: understand, that in payment of his folly and hardiness, he
shall lose his life. Let there chance what will happen, said Rosicleer, for
this fear shall not cause me to stay the using of all my power and strength,
for so high a prince. And so without any staying, he went forwards. He had not
gone far, when he came to ye sight of a thing of great compassion and grief,
where as was done the greatest cruelty yt ever was hard done to any person:
which was, that in ye midst of ye plain, there was two high and mighty
trees, a little distance the one from ye other: and in the midst between them,
there was hanged a man, having each arm tied unto one of the trees, by the
wrystes, and the cords wherewith he was bound, was two long and small serpe^ts,
the which did not only serve for to tie his wrists, but also with their heads
they reached unto his neck and breasts, whereas they did byte him in such sort,
yt they made him full of holes. His feet likewise was tied unto those trees, with
other two serpents, who entreated him as ye others did. Likewise there was upon
one of those trees, a Uulter, who at sundry times descended down, and with her
sharp and hard bill, she picked his belly, and opened it unto ye guts, whereon
she fed, which was ye occasion yt this unhappy man gave this terrible shrikes,
with out resting. At the foot of those trees there was a fierce serpent with wings,
who was the keeper of ye tormented man. The which serpent was of more then.xv.
foot of length, and had but two feet, which was in ye midst of her body, and
each foot had five claws, which were great and sharp. She had on her head two
great horns and sharp, and gored with them as a Bull does, and out of her
mouth she had two great tusks, her wings showed her to be of great lightness.
And about.xxx. paces from her was an armed knight, of a large and high stature,
he lacked no armor from the head unto ye foot. He had hanging at his neck by
a string of gold, a very rich and well garnished sword, who when he saw
Rosicleer, with a hasty and large pase, he came toward him, and when he came
nigh him he said: Tell me gentle knight, what do thou seek here in this
place of great harm and danger: therefore return back again, for that
thou can not find here any other thing but death. Rosicleer in the mean
time that he was saying these words, he was beholding his face, for by reason
that he brought the visor of his Helm up, he might well perceive, and did
plainly see and perfectly know him, to be the courageous Prince, Oristedes,
and Rosicleer answered him and said: Thy words are not agreeable unto thy
person and estate, worthy Troyan, neither is it for such a knight as thou art,
to persuade me to ^ake this counsel, and to leave to show my self of what
lynage and blood I do defend, and likewise what I am bound by order of
Knighthood to do. The fear of death shall not cause me to move back one
foot. This Troyan did laugh at that which Rosicleer did say, and said, well
seeing that thou do esteem thy self of so great valor, procure to overcome
me. And in saying these words, with great lightness this Troyan leapt in with
Rosicleer, and with his strong arms, he clasped him about the middle, and
procured by casting him about to overthrow him, in such sort, that he had
almost over thrown himself, but the Prince laid such hold with his hands,
embrasing the Troyan, that betwixt them there began a terrible wrestling, each
one procuring by polisie to overthrow the other. The Troyan did force himself
by little and little to carry Rosicleer toward the place whereas the Serpent
was, but Rosicleer perseuing it, did procure to make resistance, using policies
for to clear himself from that peril. But always he found that the Troyans
strength did not increase. And by reason that the mighty strength of Rosicleer
was such, the Troyan could not by his force make any resistance, but that he
must needs be carried out of a compass that was marked, of just thirty paces
from the place where as the Serpent was. And when that he had brought him out
of that compass, not being able to make resistance, the Troyan fell to the
ground without any feeling, leaving Rosicleer somewhat discomforted. But yet he
saw that for to go forwards in his enterprise, it was requisite to join
battle with that flying Serpent. And without resting himself, he strayte
ways took a great and mighty spear, and with a valyant courage he went
toward the place whereas the Serpent was, who seeing him coming, and that he
was within the compass, she put her self on foot, and beating with her
wings, she gave two wonderful shrykes, and with great lightness like a
byrd, she came toward Rosicleer, puffing out of that terrible mouth a mighty
thick smoke like unto a mist. This valiant and courageous knight when he saw
her coming he put the great end of his spear unto ye ground, and firming it
fast with both his hands, the point forwards, he tarried her coming. This
furious Serpent without making any account of the spear, with the great desire
she had to lay hold on the knight, put her self forwards with great fury, so
that the spear chanced into one of her great and wide nosethrills, that
almost it ran up into her brains, but if he had held the point of the Spear
a little lower, he had given the most worthiest blow in all the world, but yet
for all that it did not let to make a mortal wound. This furious serpent with
the great fierceness she had she brake the spear, so that there remained in
her head more then two spans thereof, and therewith she stroke at the knight
with her nails so terrible a blow, that she overthrew him, in such sort, that
he tumbled on the ground. The beast who was troubled and astonished with that
cruel wound, and again by reason of ye great swiftness and fury she could
not take any hold of his armor, but passed forwards on, insomuch that the
knight had time to arise and put himself on foot, and finding by him the
tronchon that remained of the spear, he turned and firmed himself therewith,
procuring as he did at the first to receive the blow, which he saw coming with
great swiftness, and fortune was so favorable unto him, that he chanced with
the tronchon of her Spear upon one of his strong horns, and by reason that
his spear was strong and full of knots, it was fast upon one of them, and by
her great swiftness broke it clean from her head, wherewith she remained with
that great blow astonished and amazed with ye terrible pain. The tronchon of the
Spear was driven out of his hand, so that he was costrained to lay hand on
his sword, and to shrowde himself under his hard and steel sheeld, to make
his defenc^ against the blows that might come. This cruel Serpent being
very much troubled with the great pain of the wounds, with double fury
giving wonderful shrikes and groans she assaulted this knight. The courageous
Knight who was not without great care of his defense, did abide her coming,
and stood still, and the wounded Serpent seeing her self nigh unto the Knight,
with great beating of her wings arose up in the air, thinking thereby to gripe
fast hold with her sharp nails, and to carry him into the air, and from
thence to let him fall down to the ground to destroy him. The courage of this
Knight was very much, and likewise his judgment, for that this Serpent had not
so soon began to beat with his wings when that he suspected in what order she
would assault him, but he lifted up the point of his sword on high, and
likewise his strong shield, that she might thereof make her pray. This furious
serpent assaulted him to take her hold in such sort, that the sharp sword ran
into her belly and guts, and so the heart: but if that wound had not chanced
in the same place, at that time the Knight had been marvelous ill entreated,
for that the serpent took her hold with her long claws in the midst of his
body in such sort, that by her great strength she made his bones to crack: but
by reason of the sharpness of the sword which opened the wound wide, and
cloue her heart asunder, the Serpent fell down dead to the ground, leaving the
Greek very sore troubled and amazed. When the Knight saw that she was dead,
he gave great thanks unto God, for his aid and succor herein. So straight
way he went to see who was the Knight that was bound at the tree with the
Snakes, and coming nigh him, he knew him to be the Prince Meridian, for the
which he received great sorrow. There he remained a while thinking how he might
unloose him and set him at liberty, and coming unto the serpents, with his
Herculine hand, he laid hold on the neck of them that were at his feet, in
such sort yt he made him to loose his strength, and to forget the use of his
cruel office, leaving ye others feet and winding about his arm, that he was
constrained to procure to clear himself: but all was in vain, for that it
was so firmly fastened about him, that of necessity he must unloose it as he
would undo a company of knots, and the more he undid, the more it wound about
with such wreathings from one place unto another, that it was very strange,
that if it had not been by the great strength he used in queesing of the
serpent, he could never have cleared himself thereof, but in the end it fell
down dead to the ground. Then he laid hold of the other, having no less
trouble with it, then he had with the first, and slew it likewise, so that the
feet of this tormented Barbarian were at liberty of his great pain, who gave
meruaylous and grievous shrikes. Then that cruel Uulture which was upon one
of those trees, seeing what the knight was a doing, with great have she
descended down for to strike and wound the knight vnbewares, which was
executed with such fury, striking him with her sharp bill so terrible a
blow, at such time as he went to lay hold on the Serpents that were at the
wristes of the tormented Prince, that almost it made him to fall backwardes:
then the Greek incensed with fury ^ooke hold on his sword and would have
stroke the Uulture, but he could not for that she was ascended into the
air. Then the Knight let go his sheelde, and with his left hands he laid
hold on one of those Serpents (having always his eye to the Uulture) and by
reason the he did quease the Serpent so hard, he was constrained by the
great pain which he received to let loose his hold, and in the end he slew
it, wherewith the Barbarian Prince did hang but by his right arm, giving
great and sorrowful shrikes and groans, the Uulture would have descended to
have stroke the Knight, but for that she saw the sword put with the point
vnwards for a defense, she durst not give the enterprise, but flying round
about from one place unto another, to see if she could find any place
whereas she might enter for to strike him, without being hurt her self. In
this space he had time for to lay hold with his left hand upon the other
Serpent, and in the same sort as with the other he did kill her, wherewith
the Pagan fell down to the ground without any remembrance.

and the Uulter giving great and terrible shrikes went away and was never
seen after. This Greek did procure to cover his naked body with certain
leaves which he cut from the trees, lamentably beholding his lean face, which
did well show the great sorrow and pain that he had received. At this time
the Greek Princes Squire came whereas they were, forasmuch as the inchauntment
was ended by the death of the last serpent, and pulling from his back the
cloak which he ware, he put it on the Pagan, therewith the better to cover
himself. Also the valiant Troyan was come again unto himself, and cast his
eyes toward the place whereas the Prince was hanged, to see if he were still
in the same torment, who when he saw him not, he looked whether he was fallen
down to the ground, supposing that he had ended his life with that torment,
but when he saw ye furious monster dead, and how the Greek was contemplating
himself upon the Pagan, then with great joy he went toward them, but much
more pleasure he received when he knew him to be the son of Trebatio,
nevertheless all his mirth was mittigated when he saw the deadly force of
this Prince Meridian, and seeing him in that plight, he could not but lament
his heavy and cruel fortune. The Greek did comfort him, praying him to leave
off his sorrowful lamentation, giving him to understand that he was not dead:
Orgalio took his masters helm and ran unto the water side which was there
at hand, and brought it full of water, and when he came unto them, he threw
thereof upon the Pagans face, and being therewith refreshed he came somewhat
unto himself, and opening his eyes he saw there his friend Oristedes, and
looking about he beheld another knight, who he likewise knew to be Rosicleer,
and straight way he understood yt he was the occasion of his liberty, and with
a grievous groan he said: O renowned son of the worthy Trebatio, how God
does in all things exalt thy fame, and now seeing yt thou have succored me in
this torment, likewise I beseech thee aid and succor me in one other thing,
yt I may receive my full delight, which is, that my loving spouse may likewise
be set at liberty, who is captive in this Island. The Greek aunswerid: worthy
Prince, my power and strength is ready at your commandment, and I will employ
all my force and polefie in your service, or lose my life in it. Therefore let
us procure to depart from hence, and give me to understand the occasion of all
this your sorrow and torment: and when that my strong arm cannot satisfy your
will, my life shall remain in recompense of my large promis. So straight way
they put the Pagan upon the Squires Horse, and covered him with the same
cloak, that first he had, and took the Squyre behind him for to hold him up,
for that he was so lean, that he could not keep himself vp-right in the
saddle. And therewith they returned, and took the way wherein Rosicleer came,
and following an other path under the hills side which brought them unto a
fair Castle. And in travailing by ye way, Rosicleer did demand of Oristedes
the cause and increasing of all his sorrow, to whom he began to tell as
follows.

You shall understand, worthy Prince, that this Island belonged unto a very
great and monstrous Giant, whom the Prince slew, for to set at liberty
certain Ladies, the which he carried captive. So a son of this Giant many
days after, did procure to be revenged of the death of his father, and
followed it so hard, that in ye end he found such occasion, that he met with
the Prince, having no other defense but his sword, without any armor, for that
he was sportinge himself at the sea side, and in his company was I, and a few
other knights, the Giant with them that were with him, assalted us with so
great power and strength, that in spite of all that ever we could do to make
our defense, they brought us unto this Ilainde, wherein we were a great time
prisoners. So one morn^ng, not knowing how and which way, we found our selves
in such order as you did find us, enchanted. He did not only make this
inchauntment to be of great strength, but also he labored for no other thing,
but to make defense, yt the prince might not be set at liberty. The ordeiner
of this inchauntment, was a sister unto Fangomadan, and for to punish him with
more torment, she put him in this sort as you have seen, leaving the Princes in
the Castle, in fast prison, being kept by two sons of the Giant, and other
knights, believing that the Prince should never be delivered out of that
terrible torment, and heerewith they drew nigh unto the foot of the Castle,
whereas they unhorsed the Prince Meridian, and determined there to take their
ease and rest. Orgalio went unto their bark for to bring provision, for that
they had there great store, at whose return they did eat and refreshed
themselves, and Meridian recovered somewhat more strength, as one yt had his
stomach clean void of victuals, the like did his companion Oristedes. So
all that night they remained there, resting themselves, and communed of all
things what was best to be done in their enterprise. So they determined yt the
next day the Greek should go alone to the castle, for if the Troyan should go
with him, it would possible be the occasion yt they would not open the gates,
because they knew the Troyan. So with this determination when the morning was
come, the Greek arose up and trimmed his armor, and laced on his helm, and
put his sheeld on his shoulder, and took his leave of the knights, and took a
narow way which lead him up the hill unto the castle, he would not that his
Squire should bear him company, but commanded him to remain in the service of
ye Pagan Prince. Not long after the Troyan being moved of compassion, his heart
could not suffer but needs he must follow the Prince. And being in this
determination he laced on his helm and took his sheeld, and with great
travail for yt he was a foot, he began to follow, and took the way which
the Greek went.

How that Rosicleer entered into the castle, and of the battle he had therein,
for to bring out of prison the princess, spouse unto the Prince Meridian who
was in great torment. Cap. 17.
ROsicleer was a great while going up that little hill, yet at length, although
with great travail, one hour before that the Sun did show forth her shining
beams, he got to the top of that hill, from whence he discerned a great and
mighty broad plain, and in it there was a fair castle, wrought with very
many towers, whose battlements were of so great fairness, that with the Sun
they showed a very fair sight, on the one side the maine sea did beat on it,
whose waters striking upon ye rocks did make a marvelous noise, which was
caused by that hasty and furious wind Borias, and on that side whereas the
Prince was, it was all compassed about with a very broad and deep ditch or
moate, and had in it but one entering, and that was very narrow. The sight of
that Castle did give great contentment unto them which beheld it, by reason it
was so fair, and being so early in the morning, the windows were not open.
The Greek being all alone musing to himself, upon a sudden he heard over
the gate of the Castle a window to be open, whereat looked out a Giant of so
great height as he had not seen the like, he was in this shirt, and covered
with a night gown of black velvet, and seeing Rosicleer, he knew by his device
that he was none of them of the castle, and when he saw and was certified that
he was none of his knights, he said: Knight, what do thou seek in this
country, for as it does appear by thy strange demeanor, thou should be a
stranger. To whom the Greek answered and said: Thou say truth Giant I am a
stranger, for I never dwelt in it, but my fortune has brought me hither,
being driven by the great fury and tempests of the sea, and being a shore I
found in it a very strange adventure, which has given me occasion to come
and speak with thee, if it be thy pleasure to hear me, either within the
Castle or without it. At such time as this valiant Rosicleer was saying these
words, he had a sight of his face, his healme being up, whereat might be
seen his fair face, on whom the Giant did very much behold, and answered.

If thou do seek me I will hear thee in what sort thou will, but if thou
do ask for the King my father, thou shall understand that he is not in the
Island, but is a broad about business, forced of necessity touching his
kingdom. I would have been very glad, said Rosicleer, to have found the king
thy Father, for that I do understand, that it should be he, who did assalt and
take the Prince of the Scitas, and the worthy Troyan. And I am come to give him
to understand, how he should entertain and entreat, such knights as they are,
and not with so great pride to put them unto such sorrow and pain, and keep the
princes in prison, using them as though they were his vassailes, who had done
some cruel and heinous offense against his own person, or as rebels against
their natural Lord and Prince, but he has been the bolder, for that he does
know they are a great way from their own countries. And I do much marvel,
that such a person as thou art, wilt consent to the doing of such cruelty, for
that it does apeare, thou art sufficiently furnished with stature and strength.
And thou semest unto me, to be a very good knight, which does bind thee to
acknowledge great modesty, and not to minister or consent unto such cruelty.
But I do see that thou art void of all, and that thou have no knowledge of
the goodness whereunto thou art bound. Therefore if thou do maintain that
which thy Father does uphold and sustain in this Castle and Island, is not
evil: I will make thee to say the contrary, both of us being to gether,
therefore choose whether thou will grant me free entry into the Castle, or
whether thou will come forth where as I am. The Giant did not show any kind
of alteration in his countenance, neither did he answer with any proud
words, but rather mittigating his ire, he said. Do not believe knight, that I
am so blind and so void of knowledge, that I do not know what is good and
what is evil. Neither will I consent that thou shall speak evil of that
which my father has done, but rather I tell thee, yt I will venture my person
in his defense: therefore I bid thee to abide, and thou shall see how I am not
afraid of the peril, for it shall be more death unto me to remain alive, with
my honor blemished, then to dye in his quarrel and defense. And I will
command that the gates of the Castle shall be open, and I do warrant that so
long as our battle shall endure, thou shall not receue any harm. And if it
be so that fortune does run on thy side, then can I not assure the any
farther, for that I have a brother, who is not so great a friend unto courtesy
as I am. Cause the gates to be open, said Rosicleer, and with ye help of God I
will make my part good with all. But yet certes Giant believe me, it does greatly
grieve me to see thee maintain such evil, as it does apeare in these thy
words. And therewith he withdrew him self from the window, and called for his
apparaile, and likewise for his armor. His brother when he heard him speak
with so great alterasion, he looked out at the same wyndow, for to see who he
was that gave the occasion. This Giant looked out with a devilish semblaunce,
an seeing the knight he said. Art thou he that have defied my brother,
wherefore have thou accused my Father for a traitor, and an evil and naughti^
knight. I am he, said Rosicleer, who do pretend to revenge the wrong and
force done unto the Prince Meridian. O vile coward, said the Giant, what devil
has made thee so hardy to make an enterprise, that Mars himself durst not
give the like attempt. Oh ye Gods, how do you consent ye one poor knight
should have so much boldness, to put himself before me, with such a demand.
It grieved Rosicleer very much, to see himself to entreated, of a proud Giant,
and aunswering him he said. In truth I have defied thy brother, who seems to
have more discresion then thou have. And in ye same demand I do defy thee to
mortal battle. In the which I think to make thee know, the vileness of thy
reasons, and the baseness used in thy words. And take from that huge membred
body, thy head, with the force of this my strong arm. At which words the
Giant who first apeared, and was putting on his armor, said unto his brother:
This knight of his own virtue and bounty does come to be slain, or else
procure liberty to the Princes, and he seems to have sovereign hardiness and
strength, and there is no reason, to show thy valor in speaking so proudly and
unseemly words, but with the fury of thy untamed arm. And if the Gods do
grant unto him to have the victory over me, there shall remain time for thee
to show thy valor. And there with he made him to withdraw himself from the
window, leaving Rosicleer very well satisfied with his courtesy. So within a
little while after he heard them opening the gates of the Castle, and letting
down the draw bridge. Then the courageous Greek took the bridge and put
himself within the castle into a very fair and large court, all adorned round
about with rich windows, and on the one side a very fair Orchard,
accompanied with very sweet and odoriferous flowers, and all manner of sweet
herbs, in the which were many that were drossing those trees and herbs, and
putting them in order, some were occupied in making of fine hedges and arbours,
and others in husbanding the trees and cutting of them, others in digging of
the ground, and others in setting of herbs, who when they saw Rosicleer,
they all stayed from their work, and imputed that knight to be very unwise to
give that enterprise, and amongst them was the Giant who last of all spoke unto
Rosicleer at the window, with a mighty great club in his hand, and for the
defense of his body a simple harness, who said unto Rosicleer: Come in, come
in, thou hardy fool, for that thou shall receive the payment of thy
indiscreet and foolish boldness. The Prince without making any answer went
on forwards, and entering in at the other gate, he came into a very fair and
paued Court, the which was compassed about with three fair galleries one above
another, the Prince received great delight to see the excellent work of them.
So not long after there descended down a pair of stairs the first giant,
armed with strong armor, his sheelde on his arm, and a great broad cutting
sword in his hand, who without speaking any word assaulted him with mortal
battle. The worthy Greek was in a readiness for to make his defense with
his sword in his hand. The Giant stroke at him a terrible blow right down, but
the Greek with a light leap made him to miss his blow, and his sword fell
down upon the pauement, in such sort, that it made a great number of sparks
of fire to fly out, as soon as the blow was passed, the Greek stroke him
upon the arm, which blow was not very great, for that he could not very well
reach him unto his contentment, yet for all that it did not let to cut his
armor, flesh and all unto the hard bone, and although the Giant did feel the
wound somewhat grievous, yet did he procure to dissemble the feeling of the
pain and grief, and with the great anger he had to feel himself hurt, he
threw his sheelde from him to the ground, and took his great sword fast in
both his hands, and returned thinking to have stroke the Greek with double
force more the^ before, but he did procure to clear himself as he did at the
first, striking a blow at the Giant, thinking to have stroke him again on his
arms, but he could not reach him, but it lighted upon the Giants sword, and
